name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on the Commission's work programme for 2020 (2019/2965 (RSP)."

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, it’s a real pleasure for me to be here today to discuss with you the first Commission work programme under the mandate of President Ursula von der Leyen, which we adopted yesterday. This 2020 Work Programme is important for two reasons. First, because it will not just be the basis of our work for the first year of the mandate but also because it sets the vision, direction and pace for the next five years and beyond. Let’s take, for example, the biggest challenge of our generation: the twin ecological and digital transition, which will affect every part of our society and every one of us.  Secondly, because it has set in motion the special partnership with the European Parliament. If you allow me, I will start with the second point, which is important both institutionally and politically and very dear to me. The adoption of the 2020 Work Programme was a joint exercise. The contribution of the European Parliament, your contributions at every stage were being taken into consideration. They were already instrumental in defining the political guidelines and now it is in these guidelines that we programme into action.  During this period, I have had the chance to discuss many different priority policies with you in different formats. A key institutional step in the process was the meeting between the Conference of Committee Chairs of this House and the Vice—President of the European Commission, which offered very good opportunity for in-depth discussion of our priorities and expectations, and I particularly appreciate the cordial and constructive atmosphere of these debates.  The discussion of the Conference of Presidents with President von der Leyen contributed to the fine-tuning of our Commission work programme just on Tuesday before we adopted it yesterday. So I would say that this special partnership clearly demonstrated how important it is, and it will continue all the way and will have to cover the entire policy cycle with this new approach and quality of relationship. If you allow me now, I will turn to the first point, the content of our 2020 Work Programme. This year, we have programmed 43 policy objectives or packages. In these packages, 28 initiatives will be legislative, allowing sufficient time for their adoption and implementation. We have also examined all proposals that are currently awaiting decision by the Parliament and the Council, and after taking the suggestions from your house into account. In this case, we are proposing to withdraw 32 of them. Some of them do not mention the new Commission’s political ambitions; for others we will reflect on more efficient ways to fulfil the objectives, in consultations with this House and the Council. Finally, under the Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme REFIT, we identified 44 significant pieces of legislation proposed for re-evaluation or revision.  We have already presented to you the European Green Deal communication, our new growth strategy and the European Green Deal Investment Plan as well as the Just Transition mechanism to support territories most affected by energy transition. The next big step is the Climate Law, which will propose a binding climate—neutrality target for the EU in 2050. We will conduct an impact assessment until summer. The aim is to be ready for the Glasgow Conference of the Parties (COP) 26, scheduled for the end of October. We will soon propose the 2030 biodiversity strategy to preserve and protect the natural environment and set out our ambition for the negotiations at the coming conference as well as the ‘farm to fork’ strategy, the new EU forest strategy and a comprehensive strategy for sustainable and smart mobility. The European Climate Bank will help bring together all these efforts, involving regions, local communities, civil societies, schools, industry and individuals.  We adopted yesterday our 5G communication, and will soon present a new European data strategy and a White Paper on artificial intelligence. We need to protect fundamental rights, but we want our industry to work with artificial intelligence and innovate. Soon, the digital services act will reinforce the single market for digital services and help provide smaller businesses with legal clarity and a level playing field by updating the legal framework, including by updating the corporate tax system. On this, the Commission will push for a global solution, but if this won’t be possible, we will aim for a European one. In parallel, we will present a new skills strategy. As regards our economy, we prioritise social fairness at the heart of the twin transitions, the green and digital ones, and as a part of this, we will refocus all our policies, including the European Semester, by incorporating the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. In consultation with social partners and all the relevant stakeholders, we are working on an initiative to guarantee fair minimum wages for workers in the EU while respecting the specific situations of each Member State.  The Commission will also review that economic governance framework and provide an overview on how fiscal rules have worked in recent years. The review will launch a broad consultation with Member States and other stakeholders to explore ways to improve the economic governance framework of the European Union. We will soon adopt an action plan to deepen the capital markets union, focusing on tackling regulatory barriers in existing legislation and structural barriers, and making sure that SMEs have access to finance, and this would become part of our wider SME strategy. The completion of the Banking Union, a strong and credible framework for preventing and fighting money laundering, the Unemployment Reinsurance Scheme and the European Youth Guarantee remain our priorities as well.  To make the geopolitical Commission a reality, we will invest in alliances and coalitions to advance our values, promote and protect Europe’s interests through open and fair trade. We will step up our engagement with the Western Balkans and we will also design a new eastern partnership strategy. As you know, we will soon launch a comprehensive strategy with Africa as a basis for our mutual partnership. The EU’s external policy should effectively address issues related to democracy and good governance, climate change, migration and human rights. In this perspective, it is equally essential to reinforce the rules—based multilateral order and as a part of this, the Commission will put forward proposals to update and reform the WTO.  We will present in spring our new impact on migration and asylum, which will be a comprehensive approach covering all aspects of migration, also addressing border security and ensuring more coherence between our internal and external policy. Under the same headline ambition of promoting our European way of life, we will present an action plan on integration and inclusion. We will also present a new security union strategy addressing both the digital and physical aspect of security as these are two sides of the same coin.  Another of our flagship initiatives will be Europe’s beating cancer plan – to support Member States in their efforts to improve cancer prevention and care.  I will also refer to the joint exercise of the three institutions and in close cooperation with national parliaments and our partners to organise a conference on the future of Europe. We are in the process of building the scope and the structure. By the end of 2020, we will present the European democracy action plan to address disinformation, political campaigning, free and independent media, and freedom of speech.  With regard to fundamental rights, technology needs to serve the people, not the other way around. Therefore, the Commission will update the Charter of Fundamental Rights to address emerging issues such as artificial intelligence and facial recognition.  Last but not least, on the rule of law, the Commission will intensify its preventive work, for example, with its first rule of law report, which will assess the situation in all Member States. This report will have a sound methodology and form the basis for future work on the rule of law.  We are also already working on embedding strategic foresight across all Commission policies by using all data at our disposal as regards the long—term trends and major shifts on the horizon to be able to design future—proof policies. To this end, I have already established a strategic foresight network within the European Commission and I am fine-tuning together with EU Member States and partners our coordination on this. I count a lot on cooperation with you. The European Parliament, as I already found out, has a wealth of data and intelligence in all its committees.  This was a very quick overview of the initiatives included in our 2020 Work Programme. It took me a little bit more than 10 minutes, but I wanted to demonstrate to you that we are really delivering on what we promised to you: an ambitious yet realistic agenda of our shared priorities for the first year of this Commission.  The future partnership with the UK will, of course, be one of our main challenges for the next months and years, and I was here yesterday with you on the emotional farewell to our British colleagues, but this was the case during the negotiation of the Withdrawal Agreement. We want to reassure you that we have committed to the maximum level of transparency as regards the negotiation process towards the European Parliament. Together with my colleagues in the Commission, we are looking forward to working together on our special partnership of trust and turning our agenda into concrete actions. We first have to join forces to ensure an appropriate, modern long-term budget that rises to our common challenges and from now on, we will all have to intensify the work on legislative decision-making with a view to delivering our priorities. The joint declaration on legislative priorities that will follow will serve as a concrete roadmap for our joint work, truly engaging all three institutions, and this will be followed by our first ever multi-annual programming that should capture our Common Strategic Agenda for Europe.  Thank you very much, Madam President, and I’m looking forward to the intervention of the honourable Members of this House. (Applause)

name: Jan Olbrycht
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The Group of the European People's Party generally supports the European Commission's 2020 working programme. The document that we had the opportunity to read (assuming that no changes were made to it during the decision-making yesterday) is a very important source of information for us on what the Commission intends to do specifically in 2020. It was important for us that this document should not only contain slogans, but very specific plans, and that is why we are aware that the procedure we are following today is specific, because we are after the elections. Therefore, we are already referring to the Decision of the European Commission at the moment, but I wanted to make it clear that some of the suggestions that have come from Parliament, including our group, have been taken into account in your document, albeit from a slightly different perspective, which does not change their substance. We are aware and would like this debate and the voices of Members of the European Parliament to be reflected in the joint declaration signed by the Presidents of all three institutions and then reflected in the multiannual programme.  This document is therefore so important to us because it shows both new initiatives and those that are in progress and those that are being removed. It is true that pending initiatives in your pamphlet are nicely called "where we want the co-legislator to take the swiftest action". This is a diplomatic incentive for the European Parliament to work faster. We would like to give back: we hope that all institutions will work faster.  On the other hand, as regards the structure of the document itself and the way it is approached, they clearly reflect what the European Commission has been saying: it wants to be a geopolitical committee. These are problems that are internal in nature, but have externalities. The effects on external policy are extremely important to us because we want them to translate into concrete language. For example, we fully agree that the green deal and the digital issue are fundamental elements. It is interesting that you point to certain elements in the Green Deal document that are also important to us, such as forest management. This document is not only a matter of the Just Transition Fund, the Just Transition Mechanism, although it has been treated much more widely. We believe that this is the right direction to actually pursue certain objectives.  The same applies to the digital economy, because in the digital economy you include, for example, issues of research, economic development. This is not just a technological issue. We believe that it is a good direction to look at this issue more horizontally.  We are very pleased that you have paid attention to the issue of capital markets in order to draw attention to certain social elements. This is very important for us as a Christian Democratic party. We also note very important wording, for example – as we have often said – the 'Strategy for Africa' is referred to in your document as the 'Strategy with Africa', not for Africa. It seems to me that this is a very important political declaration on how the Commission intends to act: in partnership with Africa, not for Africa. It seems to me that this is a very good approach and we should take this into account. We also note with attention that you want to draw up annual reports on the rule of law for all Member States. We believe that this is the right direction and should be done.  Finally, a critical remark – if the Commissioner allows it – the MFF is not only a method for us, it is one of the important, important objectives, because it is followed by policies. At your, the MFF is like a method that hides behind all your goals. For us, the MFF is simply a goal that we want to achieve, and we hope that you, as an honest broker, will help you to do it as soon as possible, because the MFF is not the work of accountants. The MFF is a discussion about politics and what you have to do. So the European People's Party supports your 2020 action plan and we will look closely at how it will be implemented, but we are also declaring aid.

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Mr Vice-President, our political family welcomes the fact that our main proposals on ecological, social and economic transformation that the European Union needs have been incorporated into this work programme. This is an excellent example of cooperation between you, Mr Eef-Soviet, and this Parliament.  In general terms, the Commission has correctly identified the challenges currently encountered by the European project and the tools we need to implement policies. But as you well know, the devil is always in the details, and we also consider the proposal to be unaccuracy and have certain ambiguities. We would therefore like to recall one issue: that our political group's support for the Commission is not a blank cheque, and we will therefore be very vigilant in verifying that each and every proposal reflected in this work programme is actually fulfilled. While the work programme incorporates the tools needed to implement the Green Pact through a fair transition in all regions, we regret that it does not include the 55% emission reduction target by 2030. The climate emergency, recently declared in this Parliament, demonstrates our strong commitment to combating climate change, and the same commitment we expect from the Commission and the Council. Otherwise climate neutrality by 2050 will remain an empty promise, and we cannot afford it.  We would also have wanted a broader approach on the part of the Commission that recognises the opportunity that migration represents to meet the demographic challenge and the maintenance of the welfare state. In addition, we have an obligation to address humanely the integration of refugees into our societies. Yesterday this Parliament was holding a debate on the situation of refugees on the Greek islands, which I think is the clear example that we cannot wait another minute. We are talking about life, the dignity of thousands of people who are waiting for a solidarity and responsible response from the European Union. Solidarity also means turning the European Pillar of Social Rights and its twenty principles into reality, including the 'child guarantee' that eradicates poverty and a legal framework that guarantees living minimum wages for workers.  Solidarity is also making an effort in the European project for those neighbours who have made an effort to embrace our laws and values. That is why we will continue to defend the need for the opening of accession negotiations with Northern Macedonia and Albania.  Solidarity also means the protection and strengthening of our democracies, hence the need for a new mechanism to safeguard the rule of law.  But let's be serious. This can only be achieved if there is an agreement in the Multiannual Financial Framework. And here I would like to call on the Council's responsibility to take on the need for agreement in this area in order to be able to address all these challenges; otherwise we will be unable to put in place all the tools we need right now. We have a duty to keep our promises. We therefore ask the Commission and the Council to ensure that, through a joint commitment, we make possible the Union that citizens need.

name: Dacian Cioloş
text: on behalf of the Renew group. – Madam President, Mr Vice-President, it is an opening year for the Commission and Parliament. This Commission shares with Parliament an ambitious vision, with the two pillars, the Green Pact and Digital Transformation, which will completely reset the European economy and way of life.  The results of this mandate will depend heavily on the ability to deliver projects on the basis of this vision, but also to identify the resources to enable it to be implemented. An ambitious and appropriate multiannual budget is needed, but it will most likely not be enough to support Member States and the private sector to finance the restructuring of economies. I expect solutions from the Commission to integrated financial instruments, but complementary to the multiannual budget.  The legislative projects we are waiting for must come up with solutions. The European Union is perceived too much as an inflationary producer of rules and rules. We will increase confidence in European added value to the extent that the decisions taken here will generate wealth, produce added value, complementary to what Individual Member States can do, and this is the great challenge of the European Union.  The Renew Group will not just stand by and wait for proposals and results from the Commission. We have already come up with ideas about how we think the migration problem could be solved, how the Green Pact could be implemented. In the coming days, we will also present a vision of how we believe that support and regulation of artificial intelligence should be addressed.  Beyond welfare, the European Union must assure citizens not only that they can move, study and work throughout its territory, but also that, in all Member States, European values, the rule of law are respected. And the violation of the rule of law must also have consequences, regardless of what Member State it is, and from this point of view, the work programme presented is insufficient, it is not sufficiently clear.  Starting next week, the UK will become a third country. We need to learn all the lessons from what happened with Brexit and perhaps improve the way the European Union works, and the Conference for the Future of Europe can be the generator of these new ideas.  We want a European Commission that is a partner of Parliament in putting this debate into practice with citizens, because the European Union that we want to share with the citizens who sent us here must be one that builds vision and offers solutions.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, this week is indeed a traumatic one for the European Union. It’s a dramatic event that a Member State would leave, and it’s an immensely sad one as well. But I refuse to accept this historic mistake as the end. It will neither it put an end to the friendship between the people of Great Britain and on the European continent, nor will we give up hope that the UK will return home at some point – here where it belongs, to the European family. But while this week is a very sad moment, it’s not a moment at all that brings us closer to any end of the EU, for example, as some who brought about Brexit might have wanted it to: quite the opposite. If we didn’t have the EU already, it would now be the perfect moment to invent it, and the Europeans have come together because there are problems that you can only solve together and because together they are stronger in whatever challenge appears in the world. And there are plenty of challenges today, and we need to address them together. And that’s why it’s so important this week also to discuss the work programme. This work programme will be the chance to prove what we are worth. Commissioner, you mentioned in your speech the climate crisis, which is indeed a huge challenge that every state and every continent is affected by, and it’s high time for urgent action. We’re very happy that this Commission puts an emphasis on initiatives tackling the climate crisis as well as the dramatic loss of biodiversity on our planet. It is, of course, way too early to say if they’re going to be sufficient; that will depend on the details of your proposals. But also it will depend on whether a majority of this House will support ambitious climate legislation, not to mention the Member States as well, which we need to have on board. Therefore, it will depend on all of us how much climate action the EU will undertake and how much the EU will contribute to the global efforts to save the planet after having contributed – actually, a lot – to its destruction in the past. The Commission is also the guardian of the Treaties, and you mentioned some action in that regard to make sure that Member States don’t deviate from the rule of law, and it is time to put our common commitment into action. This year will show which way the Commission is heading, and we need courageous steps forward into a new European Union.

name: Nicolaus Fest (ID).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to reprimand the chair of the sitting here. I have no desire to somehow go over the flags every three minutes with ushers ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: It is not your position to rebuke the chair of the meeting. That is not something you are entitled to. (Interruption) You don't have the microphone at the moment. (Interruption) We will clarify these questions. But one thing is quite clear: the rules have been clarified, and we saw it that way yesterday in the Brexit debate. Only someone who abides by the rules gets the floor. The rules have now been clarified several times. If you do not agree with the rules as they are interpreted, then there are ways to complain. In any case, we will no longer discuss this in the plenary debate. So if you have the flags on the desk, you don't get the floor.

name: Jérôme Rivière (ID).
text: Madam President, I would have liked to know which section of the specific regulation you are referring to so that I can cut off my colleagues.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The honourable Member has taken the time to reprimand the chair of the meeting. This is not something that a Member of the House is entitled to in its form. There is no formal reprimand from a member of parliament. This has something to do with respect for the chair of the meeting. I have referred to Mr Fest's substantive question – not even for the first time, and we have now clarified this several times – and I think we should now use the time elsewhere, and do so for the debate.

name: Harald Vilimsky
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. So far, I have always criticised the European Commission in very clear terms. Today I would like to make an exception and praise the European Commission accordingly, because the programme presented by the European Commission is truly magical. They manage to simply conjure up the entire asylum and migration issue. They simply manage to conjure up the currency problem with zero and negative interest rates. They simply manage to conjure up the social and labour market issues. But what you're doing is conjure up a green deal that you want to take even more money out of people's pockets. If you are kind, you could say that this is a Harry Potter Commission. If you are more unfriendly, you could say that you use political voodoo methods. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for Yesterday, the British left this Union here. I can only appeal to you: if the next country is not to leave this Union, then you must concentrate on the major and important tasks. These are migration and asylum, economy and currency, social affairs and the labour market. One expects this community to perform, and not on any conjured-up side issues.

name: Lucia Ďuriš Nicholsonová
text: for the ECR Group. – Madam President, one thing cannot be denied on the European Commission's agenda, which is that it wants to get closer to the people. In some cases, however, I feel that this is unnecessary populism. This is the european minimum wage project, for example. This is a project that will employ us for at least two years, but will not bring real added value, because already today 22 of 28 or 27 European countries already have a minimum wage institute. And, of course, those citizens' expectations are high, especially with regard to the new Member States. People expect to start getting a much higher wage overnight. So there will be disappointment, and such disappointment is then water on the mill for the various nationalists who want to break up the European Union's amazing project. What I appreciate about the programme is that digitalisation, adaptation to demographic change and, in particular, the so-called child-guarantee, have got there, because I believe that children in the European Union must have access to quality services. The new Commission has promised not to hesitate to significantly enforce European legislation. I would just like to point out that for more than a year, Slovak and other citizens in Austria have been waiting for such an approach, which has started indexing family allowances and is therefore quite wrongly receiving less for their children.

name: Manon Aubry
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, this week marks a turning point in the history of the European Union with the departure of the United Kingdom. The worst thing would be to learn no lessons from it and to continue as before, without realizing the gradual distance between the European Union and the peoples of Europe. It is this challenge that should guide your work programme for the year 2020 and, for that, let us listen directly to the voices of European citizens. I wanted to talk to you about Leah, whom I met during a civil disobedience action on climate, which hopes for a complete break with the economic model that is destroying our planet. The ambition of a climate law might have reassured her, but what will be her surprise when she discovers that your green pact pursues the dogma of growth at all costs, without questioning its impact on the climate. Leah, like all young people mobilized for the climate, demands consistency. Imagine his incomprehension at the products of agribusiness, which flood his supermarket and which are financed by the common agricultural policy. Imagine his anger, too, at the multitude of free trade agreements that the European Union still plans to sign. Instead, Leah hoped that the European Union would promote trade in products that did not go around the world three times before arriving in her basket. But the border tax has disappeared from your priorities for 2020. Leah aspires to a real social and ecological Green New Deal and this requires means. Your revision of the European semester should give states the financial levers to invest in the ecological transition. I also wanted to talk to you about Marie, a nurse who has been on strike for months to defend our dying public hospitals and mobilized against the breakdown of our pension system. Marie, on the other hand, does not understand why the European Union has encouraged the privatisation of our public services and social protections throughout Europe. Pierre worked for Castorama, but lost his job, relocated to Poland because the cost of work is cheaper. Pierre is angry at this social competition and will not settle for a discounted European minimum wage that refuses social harmonisation from the top. Kevin, also a bicycle delivery driver, needs European regulation of platforms to stop the exploitation of uberated workers. He is outraged that nothing has been done for years. Leah, Marie, Pierre and Kevin also do not understand why their taxes are rising when multinationals have stopped paying them and can no longer see the influence of lobbyists on European decision-makers. But no matter how much I looked in your work programme, there was no record of the ethical control authority that you had promised. Hear these angers, expectations, hopes, too, and act. If you do not do it for our group of the European Unitarian Left or for the parliamentarians here in this Chamber, then do it for Leah, for Mary, Pierre, Kevin and so many other European citizens who will not forgive you if you persist in pursuing this year again the same recipes that are responsible for the climate crisis and the explosion of inequality.

name: Ivan Vilibor Sinčić (NI).
text: – Dear Vice-Presidents, Commissioner Šefčoovich, you mentioned in your Commission programme for 2020, among other things, the role of democracy in foreign policy. Here we deal, we often have on the agenda the topics of democratic standards in Indonesia, Hong Kong, Bolivia, Venezuela, countries of Africa, however democracy is not sufficiently developed even in the countries of Europe, here in our backyard. I will tell you this on the example of Croatia. Namely, in 2014 we had 500,000 more voters than residents. So half a million more voters than residents on a country of some four and some million inhabitants. Today, the situation, tentatively speaking, is slightly better, only somewhere 200,000 more voters than residents. There are frequent votes of people who have died, therefore, the dead, it is possible to vote for other people, you can come to the polling station with several ID cards, round up for these people, because there is no voter signing anywhere, to really prove that this and that was at the polling station. Furthermore, the constituencies are the result of electoral engineering, they are illogical, there is even a 2010 opinion of the Constitutional Court stressing that it is not, therefore, equal to the right of voting that some units are too large, some too little. All this is something that the Croatian establishment does not want to change because it draws its electoral advantage from it. It is this political system that is the generator of corruption in Croatia, and therefore in Europe. And that is why it is absurd that Croatia has received a commissioner for democracy.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. I think that the Commission has presented a really ambitious programme for 2020 and has also set the right priorities, but – as has already been mentioned – it is, of course, important for implementation. And in doing so, I say, quality takes over quantity. So, Mr Vice-President, I would rather have an assessment of the impact of the law rather than regulation, which is then more of a burden on the citizens. On the priorities: there has already been a lot of talk about the green deal, and I am giving it to myself today. I would like to highlight three other points: firstly, I think it is good that a basis for discussion on artificial intelligence and a data strategy will be presented very soon. I was also very pleased to read that the NIS directive is about to be processed. Cybersecurity is also a key element in guaranteeing secure data transfer in the European Union. I am very pleased that an industrial strategy is also to be presented in March, and above all I am pleased that the focus will also be on small and medium-sized enterprises. In our family businesses, in our small and medium-sized enterprises, there are jobs, jobs are created, our young people are being trained! In this respect, I think it is a good thing that the new Commission is also placing particular emphasis on SMEs in the European Union. Last but not least, migration is one of the core issues. Here too, I am confident and waiting for the new proposals. If we do not solve the problem, we will also have a problem in the European Union in the long term.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, our group has presented a work programme with our priorities in recent days, and I am pleased to welcome the fact that many of these things are now also the points taken up by the Commission. However, I must stress that we still expect more on issues that are central to us. We expect more on a new pact on immigration, focusing on solidarity between states and the creation of safe and legal channels for entry into Europe. We expect more on fairer taxation, which will hit the tax avoidance of big companies. Above all, we expect more on resources, on the budget, which we know is not only up to the Commission but also to the Heads of State or Government.  But without resources, Vice-President Šefčovič, little is being done. On the Green Deal, for example, on which the whole world is looking at what we are doing, the thousand billion envisaged by the Commission are fine, but we still believe that we need more fresh money for the Just Transition Fund, but that it does not come from cohesion funds or agriculture. We continue to believe that, if we do not involve the States in this green transformation, which is also the transformation of our economic model, we will not have the results that we hope for. There is no real commitment in this programme to the revision of the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact, which we should begin to call the Stability Pact. Our priority is growth because without growth there is no stability and growth is achieved if we give more flexibility to states for investment, especially green ones for the ecological transition, by discompinging them from the deficit-to-GDP calculation. Vice-President, we have great challenges ahead of us and I am convinced that together we can really do more.

name: Malik Azmani (Renew).
text: – Madam President, this week I was present at a commemoration in Auschwitz-Birkenau with a Renew Europe delegation, and yesterday we listened to the impressive words of Auschwitz survivor Liliane Segre. Her memories are a dark reminder of what a world without respect for liberal values looks like. They are a reminder that we cannot take these values for granted. Anti-Semitism still exists on our continent. The rule of law is still under pressure in the EU. Renew Europe welcomes the ambition of the Commission to make European values and rule of law a priority. But ambition is not enough. We need concrete action: a rule-of-law mechanism. And there are more challenges that deserve our attention. We urgently need a sustainable European approach to migration to regain control. A renewed Migration and Asylum Pact was launched a few weeks ago: a comprehensive answer. But we did our homework, and now it’s time for the Commission to act. The transformation of our economy into a competitive green digital and innovative powerhouse is another main priority for us. And on the world stage we should be leveraging our economic power, combined with strong diplomacy, security and defence policies. Only then do you become a stronger global actor, and I call upon the European Commission to embrace Renew Europe’s ambitions to deliver on the promise of Europe.

name: Heather Anderson (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I am so honoured to be able to speak to you this morning on behalf of the people of Scotland. I thank you for the warmth of your welcome over the last four weeks and I am so pleased to have settled status for four days as an MEP. I wish with all my heart that we could continue to have the conversations we have started with you about the Green Deal, sustainable food and farming, a just transition, pesticide, reforming the common agricultural policy (CAP), but for now, we can’t. But I know you will do these discussions justice. My plea today is for you to remember Scotland in your work programme. Just imagine how difficult it is for a country like Scotland, which has pledged its allegiance to the European Union on no less than three occasions, to be taken out against our will and without our consent. We do not live in a United Kingdom; we live in a disunited Kingdom, and Brexit is not the settled will of the Scottish people, but we are resilient and we have long memories. We have shared a long history with you in Europe, both before our current union with England and hopefully in the future. Tomorrow, the Scottish Government will publish the strategic priorities for Scotland in the EU. We know our best future is with you, and when the people of Scotland have to choose between two unions, they are deciding to choose the European Union.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Next on the list of speeches is Mr Rivice. Mr Rivice has been pointed out that only Members who abide by the rules are given the floor. He has chosen not to follow the rules, and that is why Mr Lundgren is now speaking.

name: Jérôme Rivière (ID).
text: Madam President, if I am now bowing the French flag, it is certainly not to pay tribute to this House or to concede defeat, but to have the opportunity to address the Commission and my colleagues and take a date. Today, as you know, there is nothing in the internal rules of our Assembly to prohibit the presence of this flag, which is protected by the French Constitution in Article 2 and by legislation. But this tricolour flag embodies all that this Commission and this project of the European Union has come to hate today. You hate nations just as much as you hate people. Alexander Solzhenitsyn warned us a long time ago: "The European Union carries with it the ferments of totalitarianism". He knew what he was talking about. Yesterday, ladies and gentlemen, we all listened with emotion to Mrs Segre. And as we commemorated the liberation of the Auschwitz camp, she explained her emotion at entering this European Parliament. Twice, she explained how moved she was to have seen all these flags, flags of nations, together. She was not particularly moved by the European flag. Listen to her, hear her! Your project is collapsing, people can't take it anymore from a bureaucracy that gags them. And in the face of the people, you must give in. On Friday, the British leave the European Union. You managed to disgust them. This European project was a beautiful project. History will judge you and it will be severe: fear that this first departure will be a huge breach in the totalitarian wall you are raising.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: As you can see, we have nothing against flags. That's why they're all hanging behind us, very prominent and very big. We are all proud of our flags, but together and not on each table individually.

name: Peter Lundgren (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I was going to focus on the point a new push for European democracy. We'll see that in here today. Europe's vision of democracy is that of the EU – and only that of the European Union. No other visions of democracy are accepted. Then you are considered to be deviant. The EU deeply abhors national self-determination and makes every effort to destroy the sovereignty of nations. We have now got a new rule in this House that we can no longer have any flags in the premises. Then I wonder whether the flags above the Presidency will be removed when we return for the vote in about an hour' s time. Will the EU flag be removed? Surely a ban must be fairly consistent. I can accept if it is the case that we must not have flags in this hall. Then I also expect the flags hanging up here, including the European flag, to be taken down.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: I would remind you that the Commission's work programme for 2020 is on the agenda and the speakers are actually required to stick to this issue. But it seems to be so emotional with the flags. If you want to use your speaking time for this, then so be it.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Yesterday we voted on Brexit – the end of a years-long process that could have given rise, and should have given rise to, serious self-criticism. Nevertheless, I note that it is business as usual for the Commission.  I have a very serious question. Why is the Commission not building its work programme on the UN's sustainability objectives? Are we in Europe too remarkable to follow them? That is a very serious matter. Instead, you come up with your own titles as 'a stronger Europe in the world' and 'promote the European way of life', whatever it is. It's not serious, and it's not going to be good either. I would like to underline three things. Firstly, the climate and biodiversity must be put first. A climate law for 2050 is not enough. We will have binding targets of 70% for 2030. You must have that with me. Secondly, we need a plan for equality – not charity, not the minimum, not crumbs. We are facing an equality crisis. This should have been there. Thirdly, we need a plan for democracy and the rule of law. It's not a condition that you can opt out of. That is fundamental to our work. It's missing.

name: John David Edward Tennant (NI).
text: – Madam President, after the historic vote yesterday, colleague Terry Reintke asked this Parliament to sing Auld Lang Syne. The people of Europe are our friends: they always have been and they always will be. We have no quarrel with the people of this incredible continent, but merely the political structures and the institutions to which we say good-bye tomorrow. We don’t forget old acquaintances, but we sing Auld Lang Syne on New Year’s Eve for a different reason. We remember the old year but we also look forward to the new. We don’t lose our old friends but we forge new relationships and make new resolutions for the future. In the coming months there will be intense negotiations, and they will dominate the Commission’s work programme to a great extent. This will be, unfortunately, the last time I speak in this place, and I bid you all a fond farewell. However much we may have disagreed on issues, I bear no malice towards any of you. There’s so much I could say but so little time in which to say it. So I’ll mention only one thing that’s so close to my heart. I ask, in the spirit of cooperation, one simple thing of the Commission and the British Government, which is of vital importance to me: please do not use the fishermen of the UK and of the European Union as a bargaining chip, or the vast number of people employed in processing once those fish have been landed. Please do not sell out our fishermen. They have endured so much for all the last 40 years. Please do not put them through any more suffering. So we say farewell to political union but hello to a new Britain, which will always be close allies to our new European neighbours. May our new relationship be everything it should be. Let us now work together to build that new harmonious relationship.

name: Dolors Montserrat (PPE).
text: – Madam President, today we are aware of the Commission's 2020 work programme, a fundamental programme which will set the course for the European project and which we support. But yesterday brexit materialized and we have to learn from our mistakes. Europe is the largest project of progress, peace and unity, but populism, separatists and Euroscepticism have been growing in parallel with the European project. These moves want to break what we've built together. Let's not reduce our political project to a legislative plan alone. Let's do capitalization policy with this work program. We defend the rule of law, the values of the Union, freedom, equality and economic and social progress. The European Commission is the guardian of the Treaties and all Community secondary law, including Council decisions and their regulations, which require all Member States in their entirety.  On 13 November 2017 the Council adopted a regime of sanctions and restrictions on entry into the Schengen area applicable to some members of Venezuela's illegitimate Maduro Government. On 25 June 2018 the Council added Delcy Rodríguez, illegitimate Vice-President of the Maduro Government, to the list of persons subject to restrictions. The Government of Pedro Sánchez has violated these Council agreements, as it has allowed this lady to step on Spanish soil, which is a Schengen area for hours. In view of the seriousness of these events, we ask the Commission to gather all the information to know the truth, to require Pedro Sánchez to comply with Council resolutions, because we cannot allow a European Government to fail to comply with Community law, because otherwise it loses its meaning what we are adopting today and we would move away from Europeans. Here we all come to defend the future of Europe together.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Sinjura President, fil-fatt matul l-elezzjonijiet, imma anke fl-aħħar xhur bħala Soèjalisti in Demokratièi, għamilnieha èara anke mal-Kummissjoni Ewropea li rridu bidla soèjali, economics in amminal. In din hija run s-sena li matulha rridu nibdew it-trasformazzjoni li tkellimna dwarha u li emminna fiha. Għaliex aħna mhux biss noħolmu dwar bidla imma rridu nimplimentaw dik il-bidla. Id-deäiżjonijiet does ser nieħdu matul din is-sena għandhom iwittu t-triq għall-economy li rridu fl-Istati Membri in ser jiggwidawna biex naraw f'liema teknoloġiji rridu ninvestu. Imma għandna bżonn lill-Istati Membri jadottaw dawn il-miżuri u din il-politika ġdida. Huwa għalhekk you qegħdin ninsist fuq policy serja li tnaqqas it-tniġġis, tinvesti f'industry nodfa, fl-effièjenza fil-qasam tal-enerġija, fit-trasport nadif, fit-tneħħija ta' fjuwils li jniġġsu, vapuri ma jkomplux iħammġu f'portijiet in ajruporti li jniġġsu ferm in ferm anqas milli għandna llum. Imma biex nagħmlu din il-qabża rridu l-fondi in rridu ninvestu permezz ta' Fund li jgħin lill-ħaddiema, lil dawk ir-reġjuni in l-pajjiżi li jridu jimxu minn industry li jniġġsu għal oħrajn ferm aktar nodfa. Dan huwa il-futur, din hija d-deèiżjoni li rridu nieħdu għall-pajjiżi li nirrappreżentaw in wara kollox għall-family tagħna.

name: Искра Михайлова (Renew).
text: – Commissioner, first of all, I would like to express support for the main message of the Commission Work Programme. The message is a transition that offers opportunities. Opportunities for each citizen of the European Union, for each Member State, for each region. Opportunities for a fair, climate neutral and digital Europe, but also a transition that guarantees the rule of law, regulates migration processes, supports trade agreements.  European citizens expect concrete action from us – effective work of the European institutions. Cooperation under the Work Programme is an example of such effective work. Together, we must ensure that this ambitious programme is implemented and offers European citizens a transition that will increase the competitiveness of the European economy and improve the quality of life of every citizen of the European Union.

name: Petra De Sutter (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his presentation. Commissioner, your work programme is very exhaustive but I will only touch upon the issue of digitalisation. High-ranking jobs only being presented to male shopkeepers, people of colour being targeted by facial recognition technologies, or cancer being better detected in certain hospitals than others – that is what we might get if we do not interfere with automated decision making. That is why we need clear rules on the deployment of AI, and the same goes for rules on digital intermediaries.  Sadly, in the recent past, we had several examples of online posts that were clearly preaching hate or glorifying terrorism, or content unrightfully taken down or even being prevented from going online.  We should also, of course, preserve our freedom of speech. Private companies or their automated filters can never take the place of human judges in removing online content.  Commissioner, striking the right balance between protecting and allowing is of utmost importance for the democratic rights of our citizens and we will, accordingly, look forward to your proposals in this domain.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what can we say, we are faced with the usual Europe that does not want to change anything, the usual Europe that wants to rip Italy off, with the complicity of the PD-5 Star Government. On the fight against illegal immigration, we are at zero. Malta's agreement on immigrants is a great bluff. On the crisis in Libya, with the danger of Islamic terrorism and new waves of immigrants, Europe does not exist. On the ERM you are ready to return to the office to get your hands on the Italians' current account and on the Green Deal you have built the last big rip-off: the Italians will pay 900 million euros and in return will receive only 360. I ask myself: but does Gentiloni, the Commissioner appointed by PD and 5 Stars, defend the interests of italians or defend those of Germany and France? This is not the Europe we want, this is not the future that the Italian citizens want. Italy will not die a slave in Brussels, Paris or Berlin, let us be clear!

name: Hermann Tertsch (ECR).
text: – Madam President, congratulations to the whole Commission really on the marketing success in launching this programme which is mainly based on the Green Pact. The Green Pact already evokes this motto of Mao Tse-Tung's great leap forward. It justifies absolutely everything: the condemnation of death or liquidation of production industries, massive impositions, mandatory changes to communities and sectors, regulations and controls of conduct. This is how they have made Europeans in entire sectors in large regions afraid. They are afraid, but no one complains because he is labeled a denier, and from there to civilian death today there is very little.  We're going to spend an additional 260 billion euros a year on this adventure. And all for really ideological reasons. There are some immense challenges in Europe, which are others, and we will be marking, for ideological reasons, some issues that will limit freedoms to us first and foremost.

name: Márton Gyöngyösi (NI).
text: – Madam President, Mr Commissioner, I was glad to see in your Work Programme the implementation of the social pillar identified as a top priority. As we all know, the European Union was founded on social solidarity based on economic cooperation. Now there is a growing concern in Member States of the periphery that benefits of the single market are severely uneven and that their single role in European cooperation is to serve as a source of cheap labour for old Member States. The functioning of the single market is in danger. Economic and social tension will only increase if we don’t face up to the challenges, and this will worsen with digitalisation, which you have identified as one of the mega trends of our times and of our era.  The solution can only be a determined fight against wage differences and against geographical differences across the European Union via a reformed cohesion policy based on social solidarity among Member States. If we don’t deliver then incompetence will feed into anti-EU populism. The recommendation that you have made that through social dialogue we try to draw in civil society in finding a solution is a correct one, but please let me put forward one recommendation. You should also consult regional and local municipalities because they are the ones that are closest to our citizens, they should be consulted in the decision—making process.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – In our fight against anti-EU populism, we agree. The question that I would like to ask you – because you mentioned that people in your constituency see that they are misused as a workforce – is that the European Union has also offered the citizens of your constituency a huge opportunity to earn more, and people in other Member States of the European Union may have exactly the different point of view that you have expressed, so how do you think we can come to an agreement, making the right choice and finding the right balance?

name: Márton Gyöngyösi (NI)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much for your question. I think it is a valid point. The European Union does have an instrument which is there to close the differences between the Member States – it is called cohesion policy. My only problem is that cohesion policy is misused. Much of the cohesion funds that are received by Member States are either going to corruption channels or they are misused into projects which don’t help competitiveness. I think that the EU has a very important responsibility to oversee the management of the cohesion funds so that they go into research and development, into education, to improve the use of these funds, to improve the economies of these Member States.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the energy interconnection projects between Portugal and Spain and between Spain and France, which would allow Portugal to export natural gas to Europe, have been off the European Commission's list of priority projects. These projects were defended by the Commission itself and they were granted the status of projects of common interest, taking into account their role in ensuring Europe's energy security. Knowing that around a dozen European countries now depend on Russia at 75% on the supply of natural gas, the withdrawal from the list of priority projects is in itself a nonsense in relation to the european Union's energy security interest and I would very much like the European Commission to explain why this withdrawal. Finally, and with regard to the Multiannual Financial Framework, which is at a standstill, we know that it is a complex negotiation, hampered by Brexit, and if there is no political decision on the Multiannual Financial Framework in time for it to enter into force on 1 January 2021, the European Parliament has already spoken out because of the need for a contingency plan. The question I ask the Commission is clear: is Cohesion Policy at risk for next year? On these two issues, therefore – the reduction of the European Union's energy dependence on Russia, which would easily be overcome if interconnections across the Iberian Peninsula took place, and the Cohesion Funds, which are obviously fundamental for cohesion countries – in relation to one thing or another, I would very much like the European Commission to be able to give an explanation , and particularly the situation that has to do with gas is very incomprehensible.

name: Heléne Fritzon (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Europe must face the future, a future of globalisation, increased digitisation and, not least, the climate and environmental transition. We have great challenges, but we also have opportunities.  The Commission's programme points to a stronger social Europe. It is a question of raising ambition, of doing so in the implementation of the social pillar. It is about the strategy for gender equality. It is a question of establishing a child guarantee. At the same time, there are things that I lack in the initiative. We need clearer wordings on precarious employment and part-time employment, not least for women. We need more initiatives for a good working environment, and we need to strengthen social dialogue. The citizens of Europe want us to deliver. We have work to do, and we have to start now.

name: Valerie Hayer (Renew).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for this programme of work which responds directly to the ambitious speech of Ursula von der Leyen, which we support. I would like to return here to one of the President's strong statements, which concerns Parliament's right of initiative. The corollary to this right is knowledge, it is information, it is statistics. However, as a new member of the European Parliament, I am surprised that we sometimes receive information too late and sometimes not at all. Here are two concrete examples. A technical example first: the Commission's ABAC system, that is, the register of all expenditure on European programmes, is still not accessible to the European Parliament, even though we are one of the two budgetary branches. Look for the error. A more political example now, with the publication last December in the press of extremely important figures on the benefits of the internal market for each of the Member States. These are valuable figures to demonstrate the positive influence of European integration and these are sensitive figures when we know the positions of some Member States, particularly the more frugal states, in the current negotiations on the next multi-year budget. Commissioner, we are pursuing the same objective. Parliament is a partner to be reckoned with, as you know. That is why I am asking you today to assure us that the Commission will commit to providing Members with all the information they need. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 171, paragraph 8 of the regulation)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Madam President, Mrs Hayer, thank you for accepting the question. I agree with what you say. I want to ask you, however, about the transparency that exists between the Commission and Parliament, and I give you a concrete example, and I want a concrete answer.  We recently debated double-quality products and the Commission has presented us, in summary, a report made by specialists paid by the Commission, obviously, from the budget of the European Union, but has refused to provide us with the report and analysis of experts in extenso, saying, the Commission, that it is secret. It does not give us, Parliament and the Committee on the Internal Market, the results of that study.  Do you find the Commission's lack of transparency correct? How to be paid from the budget of the European Union a study and not receive it... (The President interrupted the speaker)... the substantive committee?

name: Valerie Hayer (Renew)
text: answer 'blue card'. "I'm sorry, I didn't get it. I take note of what you are saying, Madam, dear colleague.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Vice-President, Mr. Efsovic, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for her work on In principle, the Commission's work programme sets the right priority, namely to achieve a new strength for the European Union and also for our economy, at the same time, by means of climate protection and the management of ecological crises. That's right. At the same time, however, the work programme shows a weakness. It is very general and weak when it comes to enforcing the rule of law in Europe. Many citizens have lost respect for our speeches that Europe is a community of values and the rule of law. If fundamental rights, such as freedom of the media, the fight against corruption and also the strengthening of democracy are trampled underfoot in Member States, then the European Commission must not leave it cold. It is not enough to keep lists, but we need enforcement and sanctions mechanisms here. Unfortunately, however, these are not clearly stated in your programme. We expect you to finally come up with tough measures here, otherwise the citizens will lose respect for our great European Union.

name: Guido Reil (ID).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Today, once again, we are talking about the European pillars of social rights. One of these pillars is European unemployment insurance. With European unemployment insurance, we are moving ever faster towards the transfer union, and such a transfer union has nothing to do with social justice. On the contrary, it is 'stable social', because it rewards the states that have done much wrong in the past and punishes those who have done a great deal right. Let me make this clear by taking Germany as an example: we are the EU's largest economy and we are the largest net contributor. But what about social justice? Net wages in Germany have fallen by 10% since the introduction of the euro. We are the only country in Europe where net wages have fallen. Old-age poverty has doubled and will continue to rise dramatically over the next few years. More and more people in Germany live on the streets, they can no longer afford housing, because many many people have been pushed into the low-wage sector in the past. At the same time, rents have risen by 50% in recent years – by 50%! This is the situation in the rich country of Germany, the largest net contributor and the largest economy. Social justice must remain a national task.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Vice-President, the presentation of the work programme of the new European Commission so far has been a lot of floss, from a socially just transition to a European Green Deal through an economy in the interest of citizens to promoting a European way of life. There is a lot of talk about how ambitious the European Green Deal is, but it is reluctant to mention how much it will cost the union's citizens. As far as the economy is concerned, it is in the interest of citizens any economy that employs and creates products and services that meet the needs of consumers and supports quality of life. In fact, the European economy has been so far. The European way of life is another in a series of romantic terms behind which lies the bureaucratic definition that Brussels seeks to impose on all Member States. This way of life of ours should be as european nations want it, not brussels bureaucracy.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the European Commission has set a number of ambitious targets. However, I want to draw attention to one that I particularly care about. It is the fight against fraud in Euro-subsidies, more powers for joint control bodies and a reduction in the power and influence of oligarchs. I am talking about this because two years ago, because of the incredible greed of certain people who, fortunately, are already standing trial today, have lost two young lives in Slovakia: the journalist Ján Kuciak and his girlfriend Martina Kušnírová. Even before that, The Maltese journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia had been murdered. They died because they were revealing the truth and the criminals were afraid of losing their stolen money. Many of them also came from European sources. If the Union distributes resources, it has not only the right but also the obligation to control their flows and exploitation. And enforce compliance. I would like us to see a significant shift in the protection of the Union's financial interests at the end of 2020. The Commission has the support not only of my personal support, but certainly of the entire European People's Party.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, we want to become the first carbon-free continent by 2050 and the first continent in terms of sustainable development and be innovative in terms of environmental protection. We will be with you so that together we can achieve these goals. But I would like to share with you three points of concern. The first is the budget. The European Court of Auditors estimates the needs of the environmental transition at more than one billion euros per year. This is what the Commission is planning over ten years. The Commission needs to tell us precisely how it will find the means to enable this transition. The second area of concern is the question of consistency. We cannot, on the one hand, fight for the environment and, on the other hand, continue to sign completely crazy trade agreements with regions on the other side of the world. For example, it is an environmental aberration to drive 10,000 kilometres of meat when the European market is saturated. Finally, the third area of concern is paramount. It is a question of dealing in depth with the social issue. Ecology and social are linked, if only by the upheaval that this change in economic model will entail. However, the social issue is not really addressed in your proposals and we cannot accept that.

name: Dita Charanzová (Renew).
text: – Madam President, I wish to thank Vice—President Šefčovič for this work programme and, in particular, the importance given to the European digital transformation. We need ambitious digital policies to allow European companies to grow and innovate in Europe and for Europeans to harness the benefits of the digital transformation. We need to catch up now to other big players and so that it’s us who set the standards globally. In addition to the Digital Services Act, I welcome the proposals on artificial intelligence and data, the review of cybersecurity and a Digital Education Action Plan. Deciding how we should regulate the digital world is a priority. This topic will surely not only dominate the 2020 agenda but also, I suspect, the entire mandate. We need to get it right, now, and remember the answer to our problems is not always more regulation but better regulation.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, my dear colleagues, as I recalled yesterday, in this Chamber and many times, the climate emergency is there. It is not there for 2025 or 2030. Action on this climate emergency must be taken into account now. We're not going to save the planet with a catalogue of beautiful words, I say. So we can't wait another year: we have to start this year with strong measures, especially in the transport sector. This sector accounts for 30% of greenhouse gas emissions. It is the only sector in Europe that does not reduce these emissions. That is why, Mr Vice-President, I would like to close the file, particularly on the "heavyweight" levy. Parliament took an ambitious position in the last mandate and one would think that we would be in line with the principles of 'polluter/payer' and 'user/pay' for these heavyweights. Well, no! The Council, unable to reach an agreement, torpedoed the text, and this is unacceptable. In conclusion, I call on the Commission to put forward a strong new proposal to have a 'heavyweight' levy up to scratch.

name: Gianantonio Da Re (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 2020 is a crucial year for the European Union. Indeed, the Commission will face major challenges: Brexit and the negotiation of the 2021-2027 European budget. The Commission will only have eleven months to finalise the UK's exit from the European Union. I believe it is absolutely necessary to ensure that the competitiveness of our small and medium-sized enterprises is protected during the negotiations and that the PDO and PGI marks of our excellent products are recognised. With regard to the next Multiannual Financial Framework, the Commission has proposed doubling the budget of the Erasmus programme to EUR 30 billion. Is Mrs von der Leyen aware of the commitment she has made to the citizens when she proposes doubling the budget for the Erasmus programme? The promises are easy to make but difficult to keep, as we say "between saying and doing the sea".

name: Beata Kempa (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab You say that the Commission will be a geopolitical Commission. This is what Europe needs today in a competing and changing strategic system, from words to deeds. What measures will you take to stop once and for all the construction of the NordStream gas pipeline, a project that divides Europe and strengthens Russia's pressure on the countries of our community? Strategic gas and oil shipments, security and expansion are one of the main ills of a united Europe. It is worth, Madam President, at the threshold of the new Commission's activities to refer to the values of the founding fathers. And here's the request: we want to be in the European Union, we really want to be, but we want it to be a Union that, above all, commands the mutual respect of the Member States, not the dictatorship. So what is the law of medding in internal affairs and internal reforms and linking these matters, which are the exclusive domain of the internal countries, to the budget? This is, unfortunately, a simple path to further divisions. Let us learn the lesson of yesterday.

name: Sunčana Glavak (PPE).
text: – Dear Vice-President, it is sixty-something years since the Treaties of Rome, my colleague and colleague remind you of this, and the world today is more unstable than ever before. Climate, technological and demographic change is changing our society and our way of life. We must focus, Mr. Commissioner, on equality and creating opportunities for all, both for women and men, Europeans from east, west, south or north, young and old. The European Green Deal, for example, consists of 47 key measures. Over the next ten years, it will mobilise at least 1 billion euros, so we expect 1000 billion investments in the field of environmental protection and climate. That's the investment side. The economy in the interests of the citizens you are stating is the principle of equal pay for equal work, which will be the basis for new European strategies for gender equality. It's going to be a big challenge. Just a small reminder, women on average earn 16% less than men, even though they are more educated. The Conference on the Future of Europe and a new theme, a new impetus for European democracy, is another goal. This particular role should be played by our citizens, our young people, civil society and european institutions as equal partners. Who can speak of democracy better than the continent that founded it? But we need to restore confidence in who we are, who we are, and know where we're going. This program is a good time to do it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: - Dear Vice-President, I welcome the Commission's proposed initiatives, but expect the highly set objectives to be achieved. In particular, the transition to an ecological and sustainable Europe. The role of regions and local communities to be involved in processes, especially in the Just Transition Fund, will be crucial.  I support the initiative against biodiversity loss until 2030, which is a priority for Croatia as a country rich in natural resources. That is why I also welcome the new strategy for European forests. Strengthening the orientation towards the SDGs as part of the European Green Deal is also an extremely important commitment to citizens. It encourages the Commission's commitment to prioritise guarantees for young people. This is how young people get additional opportunities for education and employment. A stronger geopolitical role for the European Union, especially in the immediate neighbourhood, enables a clear support for the opening of negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania.  I hope that the announced new methodology will stimulate this process, especially ahead of the Zagreb summit, for which I am preparing a recommendation on behalf of the European Parliament.

name: Luis Garicano (Renew).
text: – Madam President, today is a sad day, the last day for the United Kingdom. We will find out many of the negative consequences for us and for them over the next weeks. I want to point one out that is really particularly worrying. With the UK in, Europe is an education super power. Some of the best universities in the world are in the European Union. Without it, the European Union becomes relatively a minion. University College London, Imperial College London, Cambridge, Oxford, they all leave the European Union today. If you look at the most recent QS ranking of the 50 top universities in the world, there are 12 in Asia, 21 in the United States, 11 in the UK and Switzerland. There is one of the world’s top universities in Europe – the University of Delft at number 50. This is really a critical situation. We talk about innovation, we talk about the knowledge economy and yet we are not investing in our universities. The Work Programme of the Commission doesn’t even mention the word university. We have an archaic government. We have funding problems. We have a mobility problem. This is a real crisis for Europe. We need to become an education superpower if we’re going to succeed in a knowledge economy.

name: Tineke Strik (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the 2020 Work Programme is not yet decisive on the future of our common European Asylum System and that is because, at the moment, plans are designed for the new pact on asylum, which the Presidency has announced in a first speech already. The most important thing is that we find a solution for the deadlock of the distribution of asylum seekers. I would really urge the Commission and also the Member States to find a solution so that we finally really get a fair share of responsibility for asylum seekers in Europe, and that requires an immediate distribution of asylum seekers directly from the external borders. Many Member States are thinking now and proposing a kind of procedure at the borders, meaning that there’s an assessment, a screening of the asylum request. I would really encourage you not to go along with that route because that would mean more hotspot situations and lengthy procedures with lengthy detention. The Greens proposed to have an immediate distribution and, furthermore, really start enforcing the current rules that we have on reception, on qualification, so that we really get a harmonised system for asylum seekers, and fair responsibility sharing.

name: Nicolaus Fest (ID).
text: Ms Barley, Vice-President and German Social Democrat, only admits that Members of the European Parliament have the right to speak as they take their own right to speak if they at the same time deny loyalty to their homeland. This is characteristic of the representative of a party... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: We can now open a new debate on this issue. I would now ask you to respect the authority of the chair of the sitting. That is not my decision, it is the decision of the Bureau. That was already the case yesterday. If you wish to complain about this, please do so in the way that is appropriate to the Bureau. This is not a new debate. Slowly, it's enough.

name: Nicolaus Fest (ID).
text: - Good! Then I am not referring this criticism to you, but to the Bureau, but I would also say that it is indicative of an EU which, just yesterday, stands up for the rights of indigenous peoples to their culture, their traditions and also their flags, while at the same time flouting the rights, cultures and flags of the peoples of Europe. Fortunately, the British have now drawn the conclusion and left. I am sure that other peoples will follow suit, and hopefully at some point Germany will follow suit. This would be a cause for double joy, because this would not only end the subjugation of Germany to the increasingly self-governing EU, but would also finally end its petty and self-serving leadership of the meeting.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Now you have also received eleven seconds more for this performance, Mr Fest. And please look again at the many beautiful flags behind us, of which we are all very proud together.

name: Alexandr Vondra (ECR).
text: – Madam President, yesterday we had a sad day, marked with a sad song, and the first impact is already here; we are losing English as our lingua franca, as our way of common understanding, and a language is at the core of a common understanding. And we can even use somehow the opportunity with Brexit because English becomes a neutral language – acceptable for us Czechs, for the Germans, for the French, but we see exactly the opposite: everybody speaks in their mother language, with some notable exceptions, and the others are not listening at all. So, the Commission Work Programme is a full—of—ambitions goal, without any impact assessments, but there is nothing about promoting English as our lingua franca. So, my question is whether you are planning to do something to eliminate the Tower of Babel syndrome and to promote our common understanding at the core of our communication – that’s language.

name: Bernd Lange (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for his work When I printed out the Commission's work programme and priorities, I thought that my printer did not print anything, because I see only paragraph 30, the WTO reform, with regard to the external dimension. This is a point that may happen at some point in the future, but has nothing to do with external protection of the Green Deal, nor with the implementation of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals in foreign trade policy. So I really do ask the Commission: where are the Sustainable Development Goals reflected in trade policy? What next for a border adjustment fund to ensure that there are no competitive disadvantages? Where are real supply chains that are so fair that companies can assume their responsibility for the sustainability goals globally? We still have to work on this.

name: Vlad-Marius Botoş (Renew).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we have seen that the Commission's Work Programme for 2020 includes several initiatives relating to the health and nutrition of European citizens. We have the Farm to Fork Strategy initiatives, Europe's Beating Cancer Plan and more.
