I can only agree with them, but I must point out that there is an extremely important initiative missing from the Commission's programme to unite them and, more importantly, giving the consumer the power to choose knowingly, the power to be the most important factor in the common fight for disease prevention. We must ensure that all Europeans, regardless of their training, have access to accurate and effective information on the foods they choose to eat.  That is why I stress here the need for a semaphorized food labelling initiative, taking into account the nutritional intake and the benefits of food on people's health, because citizens and their health should be the most important item on the agenda of European politicians, on our agenda, for all of us.

name: Robert Roos (ECR).
text: Mr President, the European green deal is our new growth strategy. This is in the Commission's 2020 work programme. But all that is known about this is that it will cost EUR 11,500 billion. What it means and what this is going to mean for citizens and businesses is completely unclear.  Meanwhile, the Green Deal is being thrown into law, making the process irreversible. Taxonomy will steer the economy through the European Commission. A shadowy game, because unelectable Europhiles are going to determine what is "green" and what is "brown". It will be more control, more bureaucracy and, above all, more European Union. The climate is being abused to transfer even more power to Brussels. A planned economy that our Eastern European colleagues said goodbye to 30 years ago.  More money and more power. Brussels never has enough. Democracy is really far to be found. This is not what the citizens want. And with this policy, more Member States will follow the British.

name: Pedro Marques (S&D).
text: – Mr President, one has to start by saying that our key priorities were taken on board by the European Commission. This is overall a good document – a job well done by you, Mr Vice-President. Make no mistake: this is indeed an important debate and an important document. But all words that could bring the European project forward have already been written or said. Now we must act. We must act to be at the forefront of decarbonisation and we must guarantee that no one is left behind. We can’t win the decarbonisation war with an army of unemployed people, and the transition we will not be just or effective if it does not stretch over our frontiers. We must be more solid. We do need an economy that works for the people, and we need to complete economic and monetary union. But for all of this to be of any relevance, we need to put our money where our mouth is. No more time for beautiful words. We need to find the money and we need to agree on a bold multiannual financial framework (MFF).

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: – Chairman and Mr Šefčovič. The Commission acted as a geopolitical committee, but at the first geopolitical event in Iraq you were silent. And with Donald Trump's looming penalty rates over the digital services tax, you were silent. Our citizens have expectations about sustainability, social rights and a fair economy. But if they have to be defended, will you stay silent? The Commission's plans are good and ambitious, but they will lead to conflict. With America, with China, but also with the European Member States, for example on European unemployment insurance, but certainly also about the budget. On each of these points you will find us by your side, but only if you persevere. Europe's social market economy is freer than China's party state and fairer than American cartel capitalism. We will only maintain that if we continue to fight hard for a fair, free and sustainable Europe. A geopolitical committee, yes. But more than that, we need a muscle commission.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, of course, what you have presented to us here I think is a programme that no one can challenge. Personally, I think it is not realistic to say that it is the 2020 programme, it can be a programme for the mandate. I agree with all the points presented, but I now want to ask you a few things on time. After all, all the programmes that we are preparing, you, the Council, must put the citizen at the centre, and that is why I would like you to elaborate.  With regard to the Cohesion Programme, do you think that, as a result of the measures taken in the last mandate, regional disparities have been reduced? What are you going to do now, specifically, to make these disparities disappear, to be close, for citizens to have the same rights? And, with regard to transparency, because I asked the question, I ask you specifically. You told us that you have a solid methodology for the rule of law. Can you detail what solid methodology means and whether you can also introduce us to this methodology?

name: Traian Băsescu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I have looked at the Commission's programme. If we look at priorities, we wonder where so much money came from. We have the ambition to have a pollution-neutral Europe. We have the ambition to start the 5G program. We have the ambition to make a European army. We have the ambition to implement the Social Pillar. I cannot believe in so many priorities at once when I look at how much money is allocated.  That's why I warn that this Green Deal needs to be looked at responsibly. 1 trillion in ten years is far too little, and if you want to see the effects, come to Romania, to the Jiului Valley, and you see the closure of coal mines. It was left with that programme, made with the European Union, unemployment and poverty.

name: Maria Manuel Leitão Marques (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Commission's better regulation programme, I must tell you, Commissioner, is a little more of the same. Anyway, apart from the Feeds for the future platform, it doesn't bring us much news. My question is: how does the Commission think to use technology, the artificial intelligence it talks about so much, to improve its own services, to modernise its own structure, for example on Community funds, to facilitate and speed up access, particularly to small and medium-sized enterprises, without losing control and evaluation? Here too, artificial intelligence and new technologies can help to have European institutions closer to citizens.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I come from Iasi, a city on the eastern border of the European Union, in Romania, and I have three urgent requests for Romania. First of all, I'm talking about Schengen. It doesn't even cost anything, and I remind you that we meet all the conditions and that we haven't been allowed in today.  Secondly, I am talking about infrastructure and know that the Regional Emergency Hospital of Iaşi and the Iaşi-Târgu Mureş motorway are among the priorities of the citizens of Romania. We managed, a month ago, to send the request for funding, and I hope that you will speed up these procedures for allocating funds because those who sent me to the Romanian Parliament are tired of so many expectations.  And, thirdly, re-analysis and rebalancing of agricultural subsidies in such a way that we have fairness in all the countries of the European Union. I also call on the other Romanian MEPs in the Chamber to support me in this endeavour, and I am convinced that we will find the healthy solution to make these three objectives a priority for the European Commission as well.

name: Domènec Ruiz Devesa (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, thank you very much for your presentation. I strongly support the Commission's work programme. I welcome the fact that the Conference on the Future of Europe has also been referred to as a priority; I know that you personally support it as a substantive and ambitious exercise. And in that sense, I think it is also important, as other Members have said, for example Ska Keller, who is here, that what happened yesterday with the vote we had to give in favour of Brexit is an opportunity to unite more as Europeans and advance in the political unity of Europe.  I believe that the Commission needs to support the trend of large pro-European groups in this Parliament, which we believe is now the time to make that qualitative leap in political integration, precisely because that is what Europeans have given us as a mandate in the last elections.

name: Margarida Marques (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Vice-President Šefčovič for presenting this Commission work programme to us in the detail necessary so that this Parliament can understand exactly what the European Commission's ambition is for this first year. We are sorry that there is no more multiannual dimension to the Commission's mandate, but we have the idea of what the Commission intends to launch this year.  I have two small details, because time no longer allows me. The first has to do with the challenge facing the Commission to create the conditions for citizens to believe more in the European project. And therefore the issue of democracy is a very important issue and interinstitutional cooperation. A second point has to do with the financing of these policies. In other words, we European institutions can only be credible if, in fact, citizens understand that the political proposals we make also have the necessary and sufficient financial ambition to implement these policies. And then we would like the European Commission to be an ally of Parliament in this negotiation.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Vice-President Eef-Soviet, among the priorities of the Commission's work programme by 2020 are two – The New Impetus to European Democracy and the Promotion of our European Way of Life — which affect the powers of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs which I have the honour to chair. And I remind you of some unfinished mandates.  The first is to establish a mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights that is permanent, regular and objective and includes all Member States.  The second is to update the regulation on access to documents and transparency, which is twenty years old and completely obsolete, as well as non-compliance. The third, that there should once be a binding solidarity mechanism to update the Dublin Regulation and to take full advantage of the budgetary chapter on migration and asylum to address the migration crisis and humanitarian tragedy taking place in Greece. The fourth, that the article of the 'Aid Directive' allowing the criminalisation of humanitarian aid be refused. And, ultimately, that there should once again be an impetus to this area of freedom, justice and security which has the account of solidarity with the States which have a vulnerable external border of the Union pending.

name: Leszek Miller (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I believe that, in addition to many legitimate objectives, the Commission should pay more attention to labour and social issues. I am referring to the introduction of a fair minimum wage and an unemployment insurance system in the Union. In many countries, there is a category of minimum wage, but this is about the relationship to the average wage, which I feel should be at least 60% throughout the European Union.  I again call on the Commission, as part of its anti-tax fraud plan, to address the introduction of a digital tax. The Commission could make use of the existing Treaty mechanisms in this regard and move away from unanimity among the Member States. This seems easier to achieve than the proposed granting of a legislative initiative to Parliament, which unfortunately does not seem possible without a revision of the Treaty and a limitation of the Commission's competences.

name: Mónica Silvana González (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we welcome, of course, the priorities of the Commission's work programme by 2020 include the entire Green Pact, given the climate emergency declared by this Parliament itself. But we believe that the Commission should also focus more on work on external action, on how we lead and defend international humanitarian law, on how we further strengthen development cooperation and humanitarian aid.  We know that the countries that have contributed the least to global warming and pollution are the countries that are suffering the most from the effects of climate change and the effects of this climate emergency. Other regions of the world have already made progress in how to protect people who are forced to move from their places of origin because of the climate, for example through the Kampala Convention or the Cartagena Declaration in Latin American countries.  We ask you, Commissioner, to move forward in this work programme towards what to call, how to protect people displaced by the climate and to indicate how to move forward in European protection towards the figure of the climate refugee.

name: Marek Belka (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I’d like to continue this issue of the European Union’s fight on tax fraud, tax evasion and tax avoidance. As we know, the discussion on this issue is now centred on the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). That’s fine with us. That’s fine with me. The problem is that we cannot hope for an outcome of these discussions that will be satisfactory for us. Some OECD countries will be against it. Well, one thing that we can do is make our European members of the OECD find common positions, which is not always the case. So let me call on the European Commission to use its political leverage to find a common position in the EU and strongly influence the outcome of the OECD discussions.

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, however much green or social propaganda that reproduces your programmes, the objectives remain focused on deepening policies of impoverishment of peoples, asphyxiation of development and assault on the sovereignty of states, of policies of interference and aggression over third countries. They promote a so-called ecological pact, omitting the failure of the growth strategies that preceded this policy and resemits on the same neoliberal premises, on market mechanisms, without jeopardising the predatory exploitation of resources that lead to the ecological imbalances we face. A social pillar that whiteses exploitation policies and attacks social rights and public services, and these policies are promoted by the European Union with a levelling down. Examples of this are the criticisms made by the European Commission to Portugal because of the increase in the minimum wage or fixed-term contracts, within the framework of the European Semester, an instrument at the service of the single currency, which they also want to deepen, imposing more constraints on states. From here we will continue to denounce Portuguese the cat they want to sell for hare and the harmful consequences for the country.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the Commissioner said in his Work Programme that the Commission will present a European democracy action plan to help improve the resilience of our democracies and deal with external threats. Last week, I visited a prison in Spain where there’s a number of Catalan parliamentarians in prison for over two years and, among others, it’s a total breach of democracy what’s going on there. I mean, it isn’t someone from outside of Europe. It’s the Spanish Government – the Spanish judiciary – and a big problem with the separation of powers there. This is actually about that the denial of civil rights. Nothing else. It isn’t just about the independence of Catalonia; it’s the denial of civil rights. And it’s within the European Union. Tell me, Commissioner: what is the EU going to do about it? Because it’s a disgrace. (Applause)

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D).
text: – Mr President. Mr Vice-President of the European Commission, you have presented a very ambitious programme with very ambitious figures. If we achieve them, it will be very good and we will set an example for the whole world. However, everything must be done to make this transformation as fair as possible. So that, in addition to the transition to a greener economy, we do not forget the social consequences that this transformation will bring. You have offered instruments such as the 'Just transition Fund', which will certainly be a good instrument, but it will only need to be used in such a way that it really benefits the regions that need it most. This means that, if states are to submit projects for these regions, they need to be helped to really reach countries such as Slovakia, Poland, Romania or Bulgaria, that is, the countries most affected by this transition, as their energy mix consists of gas, consists of a core, and at the same time they rely still on heavy industry, on the extractive industries. , and in particular the energy-intensive industry. So let us do everything together, together and with the Member States, to make this transformation as bearable as possible for the people.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, thank you very much for this very rich debate, for all your interventions and I’m glad that I can say that also this discussion has reconfirmed that our work programme reflects our common priorities. I really would like to thank you for all the words of encouragement, for pointing out certain details upon which we have to work even more and also on some of the things that you believe that are missing in the programme and upon which we will do our utmost to work together.  I think that the motive with which our President presented her new Commission is that this would be the geopolitical Commission, which would strive for more, and I believe that with your help, with your support, we can really achieve that. I would like to echo the words of Ms Niebler and Mr Marques, who said that to have an ambitious programme is a very good thing, but what would be even more important now is its proper implementation. I found an echo of this call in many of your interventions and I really would like to tell you that we take it very seriously and we hope that with the close cooperation with co-legislators, with you and the Council, we can deliver on this programme.  Ms Keller made a very emotional reference to yesterday’s discussion and we’ve all been here and I think that the emotions and the farewell bids to our British friends is still with us. Therefore, I think that her question on how to respond to the challenge of yesterday is clearly that we have to build an even better Europe, which would be more efficient, more competitive, greener, closer to the citizens. I believe that starting the constructive work on this joint ambitious programme would be the right first step forward to meet these ambitions.  To my compatriots, Ms Ďuriš Nicholsonová, who was highlighting the challenges around minimum wage setting, I would like to underline once again that what we are going to propose is to set a framework for minimum wage setting and that we are going to consult widely with the social partners, with our Member States, and we would respect, one hundred percent, the national tradition and collective bargaining, but we believe that everyone in the European Union deserves a fair wage and that we have to be socially just if it comes to this very basic human right, which is so important for Europeans on our continent. On the infringement case against Austria, it’s ongoing. We are currently studying the response of Austria to our reasoned opinion and we will inform this Parliament accordingly once this study is completed.  Ms Aubry made reference to the carbon adjustment mechanism. I would like to reassure her that it’s already in our Commission’s Work Programme for 2021. As I’m sure many of you know, this is a rather complex task. It would require a lot of preparation, a proper mechanism and we have to be ready for quite intense international debate on this issue. We would like to see countries like China and many others who have an emissions-trading (ET) system as ambitious as we have, but if this would not be the case, we simply would have to consider a mechanism like carbon adjustment to make sure that we have a level playing field and that we would motivate also other big economies to make sure that they would work on lowering their carbon footprint for their economy and for their products.  Many of you insisted on the importance of the rule of law and I cannot agree with you more. I think that it’s quite clear that this Commission is really committed to ensuring respect for the rule of law equally in all Member States. Ms de Sutter, I also would like to assure you on one very important fact – that the Commission will also ensure full respect – and I would like to underline both words – of the Charter of Fundamental Rights in addressing emerging issues such as artificial intelligence and facial recognition. In the context of the statement of Mr Azmani, thank you very much for your intervention. Among other and different constructive observations, you also referred to anti-Semitism, which again, we were debating yesterday and witnessing very emotional testimony of Holocaust survivors, and I am sure that I do not need to say how much I agree with you and how important this would be for the work of the European Commission.  Mr Garicano was referring to the Work Programme and to the fact that, with the UK leaving, a lot of the universities which have been part of the European Union educational area are going as well. But I also would like to assure him that we are looking for ways to maintain good contacts with our British friends within the framework of Erasmus, within the framework of research programmes. But on top of that, we want to make sure that the European education area becomes a reality by 2025, and we will work with equal intensity on our skills agenda, where we are going to present our programme and proposal already this year.  To Ms Hayer, I would like to reassure you that, for us, the impact assessment is a very important one. I’m responsible for that and there will be no important legislative proposals without a proper impact assessment being done – because we know that the impact assessment offers very often the best answers to the proper argumentation and the debates we would have, especially with those who are opposing our proposals. To make sure that we will respect full transparency, we are going to establish the interinstitutional evidence register by the end of this year – just to make sure that we will share this information with all of you.  When it comes to the issue of poverty, which was raised by several colleagues, we are going to address it through the social roadmap, through the framework for minimum wage setting, as I said, and we are going to work on the children guarantee, which several of you referred to as a very important measure. I hope that with your help and with proper funding, we will restart a renovation wave across the European Union. This would not only help us to tackle greenhouse gas emissions but increase the quality of life, especially for all those who are living in social housing, and that through this measure, thanks to energy efficiency, we would reduce the bills they have to pay electricity at the end of every month for heating, cooling or simply using.  To Mr Belka, I would like to say that we are very serious about tax evasion and we will be working very closely with our Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) partners and, if there will be a deal within the OECD, we will do all necessary and take all necessary steps to implement it. However, I also would like to assure you that in the absence of such agreement on the global level by 2020, the EU shall act alone. We just simply will not have more patience to wait for the continuation of avoiding paying proper taxes on the European territories.  I know, Mr President, that time is limited, but to Ms Fritzon I would like to say that we will consult very thoroughly with the social partners and respect all prerogatives of this social dialogue because this is how we know we will get the best results.  On enlargement, I think that we have been very clear on making sure that we will come with a new methodology. We will have a very important summit in Zagreb, organised thanks to the Croatian Presidency, where we want to bring a new impetus, new energy into this process and our commitment to Northern Macedonia and Albania is very clear, and that’s a priority for this European Commission.  On the transition fund and the multiannual financial framework (MFF), to conclude, Mr President, that was the point made by Ms Bonafè, by Mr Hajšel and many others, I want to assure you that when you are talking about EUR 7.5 billion for the Just Transition Fund, we are talking about fresh money. This is how the European Commission presented its proposal. It’s on top of the MFF proposals which you already tabled and with which you are so familiar and for which the Commission is ready to battle with the Council to make sure that we have proper financing for all the ambitious items which we have in our programme. Of course, it would be on all of us to make sure that we would use the Just Transition money where it’s most needed, for the people who need to be retrained, where we need to find new jobs for coal miners, for the people working in energy—intensive industries, to make sure that this transition is fair and that nobody is left behind, whether a person or a city, or a region.  I cannot agree more with all of you who’ve been highlighting the importance of an ambitious multiannual financial perspective. Mr Olbrycht, Ms Dalli, Mr López Aguilar, Ms Niebler, all of you have been referring to the importance to have a proper multiannual financial perspective. As you know, we will have an extraordinary summit where this would be the item on the agenda, so let’s hope and let’s make strong arguments towards our heads of state and government that we need an agreement, we need it very soon – because every month that we are late with the MFF, we are already putting our programmes in serious danger.  Once again, Mr President, honourable Members, thank you very much for all your points. I’m sure that now in the way of structured dialogues with your committees, you will have even more chance to debate all the programmes and all the items in greater detail, and we are very much looking forward to it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the Vice-President of the European Commission will have forgotten to answer any of my questions: one on energy interconnections with the Iberian Peninsula to reduce dependence on Russian gas and the other related to Cohesion Funds. Given that I have asked two questions – and you have not answered any of them, it has certainly been a lapse – if you have time perhaps you would like to say anything to the European Parliament.

name: Presidente. –
text: The Commission will certainly not fail to answer the questions raised. The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. –The Commission presented a work programme for 2020. The promotion of a social Europe must also be reflected in future initiatives. It is very important to strengthen initiatives for young people, and I am very pleased to see that the Commission will provide an even more enhanced guarantee for young people so that as many young people as possible can find a job, a learner and a qualification. Only by involving young people in the labour market can we expect long-term sustainability of work and social protection systems. I am pleased that the Commission has launched a public consultation on the fixing of the minimum wage in the Member States. Indeed, this proposal is very much awaited by our citizens, especially those who are increasingly disadvantaged and at risk of poverty even if they are at risk of being at risk of poverty, even if they are at work. This must not be the case in Europe. We are also very much looking forward to the gender equality strategy that we have been asking for for even five years, so it is very encouraging to see that the new Commission is taking difficult and long-delayed decision-making.

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – We are debating today the Commission's work programme for 2020. We are talking about it the day after Brexit was voted on by the European Parliament and it becomes a reality. This time is therefore special and unprecedented. It is therefore natural to expect all levels of further cooperation with the United Kingdom to be regulated together as best as possible. We face many very ambitious challenges, such as the Green Deal programme. We are looking for a solution to an extremely difficult situation, such as on the Greek islands and their hot spots, as we also debated yesterday. We are facing many real challenges and threats, and thousands of people are waiting urgently for help, not just on the Greek islands. I therefore call on the Commission, at this particular time, not to look for substitute topics, not to squander energy and valuable time for obsessive violations of democratic principles and the rule of law where they have long been present and not at risk.  It is incomprehensible to me and to millions of my compatriots to apply double standards to countries such as France and Germany, and to Polish and Hungary. Time and energy should focus on facing the real problems that we face as the European Union, rather than resorting to stigmatisation at all costs of selected countries within the Community.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. – We welcome the European Commission's ambitious work programme for 2020 on the basis of President von der Leyen's political guidelines. The programme aims to address the in-line challenges we face today, such as climate change, digitisation and migration. We are particularly pleased with the commitment to implement the European Green Agreement and to improve opportunities for Europe's citizens and businesses in digital transformation.

name: Josianne Cutajar (S&D)
text: in writing. – I welcome the Commission Work Programme for 2020. While very dense, it provides us with meaningful inputs we – as co-legislators – need to take into account. Much has already been said on the European Green Deal, whose concrete implementation will start this year. It is definitely our new growth strategy. Nevertheless, I believe that it will not work if it fails to entail a strong social dimension. Its delivery must go hand in hand with a full implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights. No European citizen, no European region should be left behind. The fight against energy poverty and the upskilling of workers will be certainly helpful to make the transition towards a clean Europe a just one. Through its Work Programme for 2020, the European Commission has also pledged to present a Gender Equality Strategy. Women are indeed facing crucial challenges and I am ready to stand with the Commission to go forward and promote an effective gender dimension throughout all the European policies.

name: Jarosław Duda (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I am pleased that the President of the Commission has emphasised that the condition for progress and reform in Europe is to build an inclusive, solidarity-based society and respect for the rights of all citizens. I will follow the action plan on Integration and Inclusion with the utmost interest. I very much look forward to the Commission's close cooperation with Parliament in this regard.  I expect that an important part of the Action Plan will be actions to respect the rights of persons with disabilities and to remove barriers to access by this more than 100 million citizens to inclusive education, employment in the open labour market, cultural goods and services and technologies supporting independent living. I also believe that the Action Plan will be linked to the work on the disability strategy after 2020 and the CRPD. I am also very interested in the report on the effects of demographic change and the work on Green Paper on Ageing.  I would like to point out that when planning the development of a digital Europe, it is important to take into account that new technological developments do not contribute to the exclusion of older people, the reduction of their professional, social and independence. On the contrary, the development of new technologies should be geared to levelling the playing field and offsetting age-related deficits or disabilities. I believe that activities aimed at older people should be taken into account in the development of the new Skills Agenda.

name: Lívia Járóka (PPE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the fact that the Commission's work programme includes an action plan for roma inclusion in society. It is important that both the Croatian and German Presidencies play an active role in the development of the Pan-European Roma strategy, as the situation of Roma is worrying in almost all Member States. I consider it my own priority to represent the interests of the Roma, the breakaways, those living in extreme poverty, and I am ready to use my experience to help the Commission and the Council to create a complex, comprehensive programme.  I would like to avoid the bad practice in 2010 of my proposals being taken over incorrectly by the institutions. I would ask the representatives of both the Commission and the Council to keep in check. The stakes are high: we must eliminate the harmful and inefficient programmes that have been inefficient so far. We need to involve local actors in every process from planning to control, to eliminate corruption, overbiling and unnecessary bureaucracy. And the Commission's New Green Deal programme is a guide to what alternative and sustainable development models for people living in extreme poverty can be developed with greenfield economic projects involving renewable energy sources.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I welcome the fact that the Commission is serious about tax crimes. After all, the money that criminals are extorting from the system, because that is what we should call those involved, is being taken away from the citizens of individual Countries of the European Union.  Budget depletion means less good action in the areas of health, security, technology development and ensuring a decent life for all Europeans. Finally, depleted national budgets are also a risk of pressure to reduce the community budget. In 2017, EUR 137 billion was leaked from VAT only. These measures have helped to address the many problems that we will face. Coordination between countries at EU level has great potential.  On this occasion, I would like to emphasise that Poland has done a great job of closing the VAT gap in just a few years, and that the funds raised have m.in used for successful social programmes. Does the Commission draw on existing and well-functioning solutions when proposing a new law? Inventing the wheel a second time will be a waste of time and money.  Finally, I would like to point out the extraordinary importance of the rule of law in the area of taxation. According to the Treaties, tax proposals must be unanimous among the Member States. Attempts to creatively circumvent this requirement will undermine the Credibility of the Commission and strike at the basic principles of our community.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. – In order to eradicate energy poverty, which affects 50 million Europeans, we call on the Commission to propose an action plan with clear targets and directions and to take into account, in impact studies, the effects of the new legislative proposals on combating energy poverty.  I also call for the future industrial policy to contain bold measures that support our industrial base, ensure the competitiveness of European industry, create and encourage European champions. Unfortunately, we have not seen any mention in the Commission's work programme on the carbon border adjustment mechanism, an important move for both European industry and as a source of new funds.  I welcome the fact that, in the Commission's proposal on the Fair Transitional Fund, Romania has allocated EUR 757 million, or 10% of the 7.5 billion for the period 2021-2027. I want to make sure that the regions and Member States most affected will make the most of the Fair Transition Mechanism in order to have economic growth and create sustainable jobs.  Last but not least, because research and innovation are the key to delivering as we set out to deliver our ambitions, I argue that a budget of EUR 120 billion for Horizon Europe is needed.

name: Edina Tóth (PPE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the Commission's work plan, but I also think it is important to stress that the elements of the European Green Agreement and the work programme should be designed in such a way that no person or region can be left behind during the green transition ahead. I welcome their proposals to citizens and businesses in the transition to sustainable societies, but I believe that a truly 'fair' transition should not help out big polluters.  In many cases, the elements of the Commission's programme are ambitious, but there are also areas that are less thoughtful. A good example is the Fair Transition Fund, which unfortunately is too little detail and support. These shortcomings need to be remedied by the Commission. The devil is in the details, which are still waiting for you – we will be watching tensely to see that every decision the Commission has just taken puts the environment, climate and justice first.

name: Marco Zanni (ID)
text: in writing. The ambitions of the programme do not meet the needs of citizens. The proposal on the Green Deal is a mockery and suggests yet another marketing operation, which will not lead to concrete results. Without an EU mea culpa, on its failed policies, there is no point in continuing to discuss reforms rooted in the ideological approach alone. In the disastrous method, the Commission also insists on foreign policy: intellectual honesty is enough to observe that Europe continues to show fragility in the international context. In the bleak framework, we also find the Conference on the Future of Europe, which would like to involve citizens in a process of supposed change, the main players of which, however, will be the same ones that brought the European project to the precarious phase in which we find ourselves now. On Brexit, then, the hope is that in the negotiations with the United Kingdom, without prejudice to the interest in protecting our citizens and businesses, common sense will prevail, on the desire to hinder the results of the fully democratic decision, of millions of citizens. It is regrettable that the Commission's new programme lacks answers to issues of interest to European citizens: no concreteness on immigration, internal security and the revival of the European economy.  Again, this program, it just has the name.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – The work programme presented by the European Commission for 2020 is in line with the programme approved by the European Parliament for the mandate. The priorities reflect the objective of affirming the European Union through decarbonisation, growth and convergence at internal level and by affirming its values externally. The programme reflects a positive development in the conceptualisation of the European Ecological Pact, in particular through better linking the digital transition and energy transition, as well as the inclusion of a social dimension that is still insufficient but stronger. I also highlight the concern about the robustness of democracy and the commitment to concrete measures and the mobilisation of citizenship through active participation in the Conference on the Future of Europe.  The credibility and confidence generated by the work programme are, however, clearly undermined by the continued uncertainty in relation to funding mechanisms in general and the Multiannual Financing Framework in particular. The key to the success or failure of this programme lies less in the Commission's capacity or parliament's support than in the Council's readiness to take a structural and ambitious stance on the allocation of financial resources that make the work programme feasible.

name: Presidente. –
text: The following is the debate on the Commission's statement on the "EU response to the devastating floods in Spain" (2020/2537(RSP)). I would ask colleagues to continue to meet the time for us to vote on the scheduled time.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I think that the topic we are going to discuss now is just clear testimony to the fact that climate change is real, and its impacts are sometimes too real, too dramatic and too devastating. Extreme weather events are happening more and more frequently and with greater intensity. Drought and forest fires are no longer confined to the Mediterranean, tropical hurricanes travel up to the coast of Ireland and heavy rain and flash floods occur across the whole of Europe.  The recent flooding disaster in Spain caused by Storm Gloria is yet another example. Our thoughts are with the people of Spain suffering from this new disaster. In particular, our deepest condolences go to all those who lost loved ones. Europe stands with the people of Spain. We have a tool to provide assistance once serious natural disasters have occurred. The EU Solidarity Fund intervenes to assist the population with the recovery of essential infrastructure, with cleaning—up operations and with the safeguarding of the cultural heritage.  However, the Solidarity Fund is no emergency instrument and it takes some time to mobilise it. Most importantly, the European Parliament and the Council must approve the activation of the Fund and the budget resources once the Commission has assessed the application from the Member State. Once immediate assistance to the population in response to the disaster is under control, the Spanish authorities should assess the damage caused to see whether it succeeds the relevant threshold of 1.5 percentage points of the regional GDP. This is the essential condition for a successful Solidarity Fund application. The Spanish authorities are well familiar with the conditions and procedures of the fund, but of course, the Commission services stand ready to provide further guidance and assistance as required. We are currently in the process of assessing an earlier Spanish application received in November, which includes the autonomous region of Valencia, Murcia, Castilla-La Mancha and Andalusia for the severe weather last September. Spain provided an important information update on this disaster only this week, and an advance payment of EUR 5.7 million is on its way, but in the future, we know that we must be prepared to do more. What happened in Spain is, unfortunately, a foretaste of what is to come as a climate change continues. The EU Solidarity Fund brings welcome support after disasters have happened, but we must be more proactive. This is why in recent years, the Commissioner has been putting an increasing focus on prevention, climate adaptation and the risk management policies. For cohesion policy, disaster risk management is vital because local and regional authorities are the first to face the impacts of disasters because it is a cost—effective investment in preventing future losses and also because it contributes to sustainable development. In this period, 2014—2020 Cohesion Policy is investing almost EUR 8 billion in climate change adaptation and risk prevention. This includes a broad array of support. Floods are the main risk addressed, followed by coastal erosions, forest fires, earthquakes and droughts. Prevention is the main focus of our investment. Actions to improve the modelling of risk, early-warning systems, preparation of strategies and guidelines, awareness raising, grey or green infrastructure for flood protection, sustainable land and forest management, et cetera. In this period, we have also seen a large focus on green infrastructure to manage risk, like flood plains and green urban spaces. The Commission also provides guidelines and it encourages Member States to compile national risk assessments, which are an essential and necessary tool to fight the impact of floods. Besides prevention, we also focus on preparedness with support for equipment, infrastructure and training for civil protection units. European money also supports the development and improvement of the EU early-warning and information systems. Fed by a network of sensors and satellites, they provide reliable information about the development of extreme meteorological events, improving the prediction of the impact of events such as floods. These systems also enable the emergency—response community to monitor and share reliable information, to prepare to respond and to better coordinate response efforts.  Finally, we offer flexibility in our cohesion programmes. Programme amendments can be proposed and then swiftly agreed to shift resources towards areas that are most at need, so if changes need to be made, we can still do this within this funding period. The Commission’s proposals for cohesion policy after 2020 include disaster risk management and climate adaptation as specific objectives. Prevention and preparedness measures include infrastructure, equipment shelters, development of early—warning systems and training for civil protection units. Where appropriate, these measures cross borders.

name: Dolors Montserrat
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, I cannot begin my speech without reminding all those who have lost their lives for the storm, their families and loved ones. To the missing persons, to the wounded, to all I transfer our support and our affection.  Spain has suffered the terrible consequences of the temporary Gloria, but a few months ago also from the DANA, where so many neighbors have seen how their homes, their cars, their streets, their companies, their farms, their fields, their orchards, have been destroyed. We have suffered great natural and economic losses in places necessary for our ecosystem and economy such as the Ebro Delta – a unique place in Europe and third rice producers in Spain – where sea growth has caused, in addition to environmental damage, the disappearance of crops worth more than four million euros; or in places such as the Valencian Community, where citrus fruits, agricultural infrastructure, seasonal vegetables and livestock have suffered losses of up to 63 million euros; or as the Balearic Islands, which has lost its beaches, and so many affected Spanish regions, such as Andalusia, Murcia, Castilla-La Mancha or Aragon. The Spaniards concerned need a quick and effective response from the Government of Spain. We call on the Government of Spain to assess the affected areas quickly, to speed up aid, to apply to the European Union for the Solidarity Fund and to declare the municipalities concerned a catastrophic zone.  The European Union cannot be left behind. It must therefore activate the Solidarity Fund and the Cohesion Fund. You must work for a larger budget in the new CAP to have more resources that fund risk prevention for our farmers and ranchers.  An ambitious Green Pact, which protects our environment from phenomena caused by climate change, that invests in improvements in hydraulic infrastructure and the protection and cleanliness of our forests and rivers, to prevent future weather events.  Europe cannot look the other way and must act. Spaniards who have suffered the storm cannot wait another day, and the People's Party will not rest until these aids reach those affected. We'll always be with them and we'll never leave them behind.

name: Cristina Maestre Martín De Almagro
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, in just a few months' term, this is the third natural disaster we are debating in the European Parliament. And I am very afraid that it will not be the last because climate change is certainly an unequivocal reality, which is evident in storms like the ones we have suffered in Spain. Indeed, according to the European Commission's own data, more than 500 000 people in the European Union are exposed to these phenomena, a certain risk of river flooding, and 2.2 million people, also in the European Union, are at risk of being affected by coastal flooding.  Therefore, this is not a problem of today, of Spain, but it is a problem of all. And since it's everybody's problem, we have to start taking it seriously. And that's why it's very important that we start implementing measures to prevent it. But it is also very important that the Solidarity Fund is implemented immediately. We need it to show that this is also cohesion and that our country, like another country at any time, can get the support of the European Union to compensate for all the grievances caused by this terrible storm.  There are things that are not going to be recovered, like human lives, unfortunately. But Europe can also be on our side so as not to leave all those families and also sectors that have been affected by this storm abandoned.  I would indeed thank you, as you rightly said, Mr Vice-President, for speed and flexibility in the implementation of this Fund.

name: Susana Solís Pérez
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, thank you Commissioner for your words. The drunken Gloria has hit Spain hard: fourteen dead, eighty-three wounded, two missing. The balance is devastating. There are municipalities in Catalonia, in the Valencian Community, the Balearic Islands, Murcia, Aragon, which have had million-dollar losses in infrastructure and in the countryside. Sea walks, beaches, citrus cultivation have disappeared... All this in regions that depend on agriculture and tourism. And the worst thing is that this is not an isolated phenomenon; we have just suffered the consequences of DANA, and experts warn us that these phenomena are going to increase.  That is why I would like to ask the Commission here today to have effective proposals. I propose three actions. First, the Solidarity Fund. We need to activate it, but also, if these phenomena are on the rise, we need to increase the Solidarity Fund's budget so that all the people who suffer from these tragedies are covered.  Secondly, improve the paperwork. We cannot go through long administrative procedures, and in Spain our farmers are still waiting for DANA aid.  And thirdly, to improve at all levels the systems of natural disaster prevention and adaptation to climate change. It's critical to saving lives.  In short, let us value one of the fundamental values of the European Union, solidarity, because that is now when we need it most.

name: Diana Riba i Giner
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr. President, last week Storm Gloria had devastating effects on Catalonia and the rest of the state. Thirteen people lost their lives. This climate phenomenon has had an unprecedented ecological and agricultural impact and is a clear consequence of the effects of climate change. The Gloria Pass has made a large number of beaches and infrastructures located by the sea disappear, and has caused serious damage to the Ebro Delta, as well as to the tordera and Ter river basins. According to the first estimates, the impact of the damage amounts, for example, to 74 million in the Barcelona demarcation alone, or to 16 million in the Catalan primary sector.  Faced with the need for a rapid reaction, we call on the European Commission and the Spanish Government for three actions: first, that the resources of the European Regional Development Fund be urgently activated to co-finance damage repairs; secondly, as you have rightly said, the Solidarity Fund; but finally, also that a specific action plan be made for the Mediterranean coast and the delta, in line with the declaration on the protection of the Ebro Delta adopted yesterday by the Catalan Government and by agents of the territory.

name: Marco Dreosto
text: On behalf of the ID Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by expressing our solidarity with our Spanish colleagues and with the whole of Spain at the catastrophic floods they have suffered in recent weeks. It is precisely in my role as rapporteur for our group in the dossier on the UNION civil protection mechanism that I would like to stress how important it is to work on the prevention of natural disasters. This can be done, but above all it must be done through a new culture of anticipation and prevention, through innovative strategies, but also in the long term, which can help us to avoid, or at least reduce, the human and/or social costs caused by these tragic disasters.  Another fundamental factor is the proper training of civil protection personnel, citizens and volunteers, and in this respect we approve of what has been proposed in the new regulation. I would like to end by thanking those volunteers who make themselves available every day and always respond when there are these calamities.

name: Idoia Villanueva Ruiz
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the temporary Gloria has hit with particular hardness the Mediterranean coast of the Iberian Peninsula: Andalusia, the Balearic Islands, Catalonia, Murcia, in addition to the Valencian Community, are some of the territories affected. To this day we mourn fourteen deaths and dozens of wounded. Gloria has caused devastating effects on infrastructure, urban furniture, beaches, crops, shops and housing; aggravated damage, which must also be said, by policies of the ball and urban speculation of irresponsible and corrupt governments that have done so much damage to the coast.  Climate change has already very visible consequences. This phenomenon is affecting very intensely our entire country, which during 2019 has suffered severe floods and floods throughout the territory, also in Andalusia, the Basque Country or Navarra. It is too early to have an overall balance of damage, valued at million-dollar losses that will drag our economy and the population.  Today we are asking in this Parliament for support to activate the Catastrophe Solidarity Fund; changing the criteria in the funds so that individualized country cases are not collected, but the overall annual number of cases due to the same cause: climate change; stronger measures against urban corruption and a determined commitment to implement policies against the climate emergency. Let's not wait for the next catastrophe to act. We're into life on it.

name: Antoni Comín i Oliveres (NI).
text: – Mr President, last week, indeed, he was a hit for the Catalan and Valencian coasts, because of this storm, paradoxically called "Gloria", which has also affected the Balearic Islands or Northern Catalonia, in French territory, or Spanish autonomous communities such as Murcia, such as Andalusia or as Aragon. In Catalonia, the counties of Girona and the Ebro Lands were particularly devastated.  Climate change is undoubtedly the main cause of this storm. However, in the case of the Ebro, the impact has been increased by the previous situation of the river delta. Today it is time to recall that Spain does not properly comply with the Water Framework Directive, which requires sediments accumulated in river dams to be released or drained to the mouth, to prevent delta regression.  Catalan MEPs have been calling for compliance for years. Today the delta has lost more than eight million square meters of land and, during the storm, seawater has penetrated more than three kilometers inland. Gloria has caused fourteen dead in Spain, losses on 15,000 hectares in Girona and 3,000 in the Ebro Lands. What does the Commission propose to help the Generalitat defend these injured lands?

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, you cannot imagine the damage my land is suffering. A flood is a catastrophe. Two floods in a few months is a catastrophic climate change. In September the damage in the Valencian Community exceeded 1.5 billion euros. In recent floods we have not yet counted them, but in agriculture alone they exceed 62 million euros. Fields, roads, bridges have been lost. The albufera has suffered great damage; human lives have been lost, above all.  And European aid, Commissioner, does not come. The Solidarity Fund for floods in September has not yet been activated and has already been requested by the Government of Spain, and the Structural Fund has not been used for the cleaning of ravines or the correction of channels. We need European aid, because climate change is not going to affect us alone; we're at the forefront, but it's going to affect everyone. Let me tell you this is going to happen again; that damage is largely avoidable; that we need a special action plan for the Albufera de Valencia — a natural place that is unrepeatable in the world and that can be lost if we do not attend it — and that transitional funds for the ecological economy must not only take into account that the economy changes, they also have to take into account that nature has to adapt to that new economy and that these damages that occur so often in my land have to be seen with aid so that neither farmers nor entrepreneurs nor people lose their businesses or, above all, their lives again.

name: Inma Rodríguez-Piñero (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, fourteen people have lost their lives. It is the second time in four months that our beaches, fields and cities have been waterlogged, flooded, devastated by the relentless effects of climate change on the Spanish Mediterranean coast, and especially in the Valencian Community, my constituency, an area of the most vulnerable in Europe.  It is urgent that the Commission act forcefully, to side with citizens and to work with the Spanish authorities, urgently providing all the resources set out in the funds to combat the effects in the short term. But it is critical to act in the medium and long term to minimize, in the future, the effects of climate change.  That is why, Commissioner, I ask the Commission to develop a culturally specific climate strategy for the Mediterranean. We're running out of time. The albufera of Valencia, the Ebro Delta, the Mar Menor in Murcia are spaces of very high ecological value, which need to be protected and the resources and cooperation of all administrations. Not a life less. Citizenship awaits us and we cannot fail you.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I will also try very briefly to respond. I want to express my support for the Spanish people, maximum solidarity. You need to help as soon as possible, Commissioner. From my own country, the Czech Republic, I can say that we have always had a very good experience with the Solidarity Fund. But the only thing I would criticize is the length of time it took to process the applications. So please try your best to get the applications from Spain resolved as soon as possible, because while the Solidarity Fund is a very good instrument, if we are waiting or the Member States are waiting more than six months for real money to come in, real aid, it can be a really big delay.  Personally, I think we should consider an overall reform of the Solidarity Fund. Climate change will require more money to be provided to individual Member States affected by climate change in the future, and we will really need to find a mechanism to respond more flexibly and flexibly. When you evaluate a specific request to the Commission for several months and then the Council and Parliament decide, the aid comes in 9 to 12 months. So please help Spain very much, but also work out how to make the whole instrument more efficient in the future and reduce the time it will take for the state to receive real support.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the wuthering Gloria hit Spain and especially the Mediterranean Sea last week. Fourteen-metre waves on my land, the Balearic Islands, hit homes, beaches, roads; they cleared promenades from the Levant; ports were closed throughout Spain, in Barcelona, in Valencia, in Mahón, in Citadel. There were dead and missing, also in my land, great damage, desupply. And that had an impact and has a human, economic and social impact throughout Spain. Manacor, San Lorenzo, Son Servera, Capdepera, Santanyí, Felanix, Pollensa, were some of the municipalities of my land, the Balearic Islands, badly damaged by that blur.  I request the activation of the Solidarity Fund. It was recently amended in the last parliamentary term to eliminate administrative procedures. It is necessary to teach the soul of European solidarity more than ever to Spain and more than ever to these regions.

name: Alicia Homs Ginel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the wuthering Gloria must be a call, once again, to action by the European Union. The effects of climate change are baiting with the Spanish Mediterranean. In October 2018, a very strong storm gave the first alarm signal in my region, specifically in Sant Lloren's des Cassadar, in Mallorca. Also, in October of the last year, a DANA toured the region and last week the drunken Gloria hit the Balearic Islands, Catalonia and Valencia, causing fourteen dead. And in the Balearic Islands, two people are still missing, whose relatives I want to send all my affection to from this Parliament.  Everything indicates that these intense storms are going to become more frequent. That is why the regions we suffer the most ask for help, both to recover from its effects and to adapt to the new reality. The Solidarity Fund should have mechanisms that can urgently mobilize resources for the affected regions.  In the Balearic Islands, the consequences of the storm have also been twofold. The interruption of food supplies has been added to the material and human damage. And this is another reason for the European Union to take insularity seriously as a disadvantage suffered by the citizens of our islands.

name: Ellie Chowns (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, today I participate in my final debate as a UK MEP and, as a Green, it seems sadly fitting that this is a debate on solidarity within this Union in response to a disaster in Spain, and I’d like to express my personal sympathy and solidarity with all those affected. Floods such as this can no longer be called entirely natural disasters because, as we know, climate change is making these disasters, tragically, more frequent and more severe. In my seven months in this Chamber, I have pushed hard for stronger and faster European action to address the climate crisis. Today, in the gallery, I am joined by 28 young people from the West Midlands. Their voices and their generation’s voices have been heard loud and clear. We must take faster and stronger action on the climate and ecological crisis. (Applause) Although I will no longer serve in this House due to Brexit, I return to the UK to push for that strong action in my own country and I urge you, my European friends and colleagues, to increase your level of ambition in this area. I hope that the spirit of solidarity within this Union grows ever stronger, and I hope that together we can act in a spirit of global solidarity to tackle the challenges that we face together, ensemble, zusammen.

name: Mazaly Aguilar (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I wanted to show my solidarity with all the victims of the temporary Glory which has affected with extreme virulence the East Coast of my nation, Spain. Unfortunately, there have been fatalities and large material losses, especially in the agriculture sector. Last September, as other colleagues of mine have already said, there was another storm called DANA that caused further damage to our agriculture. Unfortunately, farmers still do not receive the aid promised to them.  The new temporary Gloria has only greatly harmed these producers of citrus, vegetables, ranchers, who are absolutely desperate with this situation. I am grateful for the European Commission's show of solidarity, but I would like to stress the need for a series of quick, strong and effective responses which I would say on the part of three instruments: the CAP, the Cohesion Funds and the European Union Solidarity Funds.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, it’s a pleasure to respond to the very emotional interventions of our honourable Members – especially from Spain – on the disaster caused by Storm Gloria in front of a full House because I think that this disaster clearly gives us another example that climate change can no longer be ignored because it has become a real climate emergency. Therefore, I absolutely agree with Ms Montserrat, who said that we must act quickly, with flexibility and the necessary speed. I would like to assure you, Mr President and honourable Members, that the new Commission has geared its political objective and the Work Programme to meet this challenge head—on in the years to come. I would also like to underline that I very well understand the point made by Ms Maestre Martín De Almagro that, if it comes to the size and the scope of such a disaster imposed on the local economy, we fully understand the dramatic consequences. I would like to thank Mr González Pons for making a very plastic picture – how not one, not two, but a series of financial disasters can really devastate the whole region. At this point, I would like to reassure all of you that the Commission is committed to helping Spain and other Member States if they are affected by natural disasters in every way possible. The only thing I would like to make clear here, as well, is that we all have to act much more swiftly because you know that the rules which have been approved by you require that first the application comes as quickly as possible so we can act very quickly in the Commission and mobilise the necessary funds. I want to reassure you that we would not delay it by one day: once we get the application, we act very quickly but, unfortunately, the mobilisation takes time because it needs approval of the European Parliament and also the Council. Therefore, we just mobilised the advance payments for the DANA (Depresión Aislada en Niveles Altos) disaster and we are waiting for the application which will be presented by Spanish authorities for the Gloria disaster. At the same time, I would also like to highlight the fact that the Solidarity Fund is not the instrument that we have at our disposal. The CAP and Structural Funds could be used to alleviate the pressures caused by such a natural disaster. Maybe in the future, it would be one topic to debate: what can we do together to make sure that the Solidarity Fund could be mobilised much faster? And what other instruments can we use to help the people in such distress caused by the disasters, which unfortunately, we’ll probably see more often because of the climate emergency?

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D)
text: in writing. – I am a doctor and I want to support any patient, city and country in a critical situation. We now have the power to do so in the plenary of the European Parliament as well. I will vote with both hands this. I only remind you that the new RescEU programme (which I supported in the plenary of the European Parliament) has become a reality. The programme offers new opportunities for European response to emergencies (such as floods, fires, earthquakes or other disasters). The Strasbourg plenary has already voted to allocate the EUR 156.2 million needed for this programme.  I want: 1. The development of the European Civil Protection Mechanism - which involves the establishment of new medical, technical and logistical capacities at European level - to facilitate access to treatment for critical patients (burned, polytraumatized) in the Member States in emergency situations. I want the Emergency Hospital of Iasi to be included in this process. 2. Develop and implement a European cancer plan – essential for health education, prevention and early diagnosis, but also for improving access to innovative medicines and technologies. "Unity in diversity" (the european Union's motto) must mean solidarity and health.

name: Isabel García Muñoz (S&D)
text: in writing. " Despite the denialists, Gloria passed through Spain, with heavy rains and snowfall that left thousands of people in my region, Aragon, isolated. The thaw now threatens many populations by overflowing rivers. Nearly 4,000 km of roads and 142 municipalities in the provinces of Teruel and Zaragoza have been affected, leaving thousands of people incommunicado without electricity, water, internet or coverage. There has also been damage to buildings and ships, and serious losses in the countryside and livestock. Cooperation between the central and regional governments has been essential and, together with security forces, the EME, regional emergency services, town halls and neighbours are working to respond to the exceptionality experienced. This further highlights the need to work from the European institutions, together with national, regional and local authorities, for territorial and socio-economic cohesion and to seek solutions to the challenges of rural and mountainous areas, which urgently need to improve transport and telecommunications infrastructures. Let's work together to alleviate the effects of climate change on less-favoured areas.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. – The situation in Spain is an emergency and in an emergency we must respond urgently! The problem is not only in Spain! More than two million citizens in Europe are exposed to coastal flooding. Solidarity is needed in natural disasters, but prevention measures are also needed. In addition to the Civil Protection Mechanism, we need to have an alert system that works in all Member States and that can be appealed to by all citizens. That is why I propose that in the Commission's programme you review the functioning of measures, protection units and increase prevention measures throughout the EU.

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Once again, an extreme climatic phenomenon places our immense fragility within Europe in the face of the phenomena of nature. The balance of the number of people killed, injured and of material damage should shame us as a society and should lead us to act. Also in Portugal, in the districts of Castelo Branco, Guarda, Viseu or Coimbra, Storm Gloria left a track of destruction, with people injured, houses destroyed, countless trees uprooted, cars crushed and roads banned. From here, we want to send our solidarity to all those affected in Portugal and Spain. We ask that, without delay, the European Union be able to trigger the Solidarity Fund to compensate in some way for the losses suffered. And we demand, outside of the lofty announcements to which the EU has already become accustomed not to follow up, that, in the certainty that these climate phenomena will be more frequent, urgent response strategies are put in place, with appropriate means and on the basis of strategic civil protection plans defined in each Member State.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I strongly object to the decision of the President of the European Parliament, Mr Sassoli, to interpret Article 10(3) of the Staff Regulations, namely that MePs are obliged not to disturb the good order in plenary and to refrain from inappropriate behaviour by not displaying posters or inscriptions – such as a ban on the use of our national flags in the chamber.  The national flag is not a banner, the national flag is a symbol, it is my national flag, it can not be just a banner, it can not be banned. Moreover, you allow colleagues to sometimes display symbols that are, to put it mildly, controversial. Therefore, Honourable Madam President, I demand that this shameful and controversial decision be annulled by the Conference of Presidents. Now I leave my flag here, and if anyone wants to move it or remove it, they're going to have to do it by force. Welcome!

name: President. –
text: Mr Dzhambazki, I will not open the discussion on this topic. I just want you to read carefully the current rules, especially Rule 10(3) where it is clearly mentioned that Members shall not display any banners and, generally, there is an obligation to respect the dignity of this Chamber. That is why the President decided to respect and follow this rule. That’s all I would like to say. Mr Dzhambazki, I will refer to the President on this issue but we will not discuss it today.

name: Sophia in ‘t Veld (Renew).
text: – Madam President, I would just like to request your attention for a few seconds on a matter relating also to parliamentary democracy, and also to relations between the European Union and Russia. The day before yesterday, we learned that a Dutch MP who is very critical of the Russian Government, one of the driving forces behind the European Magnitsky Act, has been blacklisted, and had imposed an entry ban, like some other Members of this House. I would request that this House stand in solidarity with other elected representatives and contact Mr Borrell and ask him to intervene with the Russian authorities. (Loud applause)

name: President. –
text: I will pass on this message to the President, Ms in 't Veld. There is another point of order from Mr Lagodinsky.

name: Sergey Lagodinsky (Verts/ALE).
text: – It’s a point of order, according to Rule 195 referring to the violation of Rule 181, paragraph 1 by the President of Parliament. Honourable chair, the President of Parliament deemed all our amendments to the Credentials Report by the JURI Committee as inadmissible. What is inadmissible about a statement that national electoral rules should be interpreted in the light of EU law? What is inadmissible in a statement that parliamentary procedures, according to the rules of this House, should be considered? There is nothing that is inadmissible here.  The President might not agree with that on the substance, but it’s not up to him to decide on substance, it is up to us to decide on substance. It’s up to the majority of this Parliament to decide on those issues. All he had to do is to decide whether it’s admissible or not, and in the amendment, there was nothing – no names, nor any other out of scope information – that would have been inadmissible. Let me state this: the decision follows the path of politicising the behaviour and the decisions of Parliament regarding credentials, especially regarding Mr Junqueras. The President overstepped yet again his authority in this case. He is not a king. He is a parliamentary president. We are in the European Parliament. We’re not in a constitutional monarchy, so please let us, as Parliament, decide on those issues.  (Applause)

name: President. –
text: Colleagues, I will just say that, according to the rules that we all have to respect, the decision on admissibility is a prerogative of the President.

name: Isabel Wiseler-Lima (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it’s about the flags. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: President. –
text: I am sorry, I said there won’t be any discussion on the flags. It was a decision of the President. I will refer back to him and there might be follow—up discussions, but not now.

name: Brian Monteith (NI).
text: – Madam President, it is in fact in regard to a point of procedure. This group, this party delegation, which was the largest in the elections, which represents over 5.4 million votes, more than the populations of some states that are members has been completely ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: President. –
text: I am sorry, this is not a point of order either.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: – Madam President, thank you very much for giving me the floor before these votes. I would like to remind all voting right now for a resolution on gender equality and economic institutions we made here in this House in March 2019. This resolution is referring to the fact that there has to be gender balance when doing these votes. All the candidates here are men and this is a reminder of this resolution.

name: President. –
text: Colleagues, since it’s the last vote with our British colleagues, I would like to thank them for all their work in the European Parliament and wish them all the best. (Standing ovation) That concludes the vote. (The sitting was suspended briefly)

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, yesterday, when we voted on the agreement on the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the EU, it was the most difficult vote for me in five years. I want to say that I did not agree with the withdrawal of the United Kingdom, but I voted in favour of this agreement because it is important that the departure of the United Kingdom under an agreement that will allow eu citizens in Britain and British citizens to be well positioned in the EU is a good preparation for the next good cooperation and partnership in the EU. That is why I voted in favour of this agreement, although I am very sad, very unhappy about the British leaving, we will miss them here, but I believe that it was not goodbye, but goodbye.

name: Sheila Ritchie (Renew).
text: – Madam President, today, many, many hundreds of thousands of UK citizens are grieving their loss of EU citizenship. I pray this House finds a way to be generous to them, to us. Do not treat, please, us as churlishly as our Brexiteers have treated you. I warn you all of the dangers of populism. We are the first victims; do not let there be more. I could not vote for this disgraceful agreement. It is, of course, better for the EU than it is for the UK: a fact which the UK seems to be blind to. I thank this House for its continuous courtesy. Goodbye.

name: Barbara Ann Gibson (Renew).
text: – Madam President, thank you for allowing me to speak. Today, I’m the voice of millions of UK citizens. I am heartbroken. The personal sense of loss is enormous; the loss of my freedoms and rights, the loss of my EU citizenship, part of my very identity that I value so much. I know in my heart that Brexit is a mistake, and I don’t think I will ever be able to forgive the self—serving politicians who have brought it upon us. Ours is a great nation, but we are greater in the EU. The UK should be leading in Europe, not leaving. I am heartbroken.

name: Jane Brophy (Renew).
text: – Madam President, yesterday in this Chamber, along with my Liberal Democrat colleagues, I voted against the Brexit Withdrawal Agreement. I did this because I believe this Withdrawal Agreement is a bad deal for Britain. There is no deal that is as good for the UK as remaining a member of the European Union. The next few months will bring us insecurity; not just for our country but also for European citizens living in the UK and British citizens living in Europe. This deal does not go far enough to protect their rights. I’m appalled that this issue was not at the forefront of Boris Johnson’s government negotiations and ashamed that it fell on the EU negotiation team to fight for.
